150194976.review:
Read the negative reviews. 5 levels, missing game elements that developers failed to complete (but are still mentioned in dialogue?), completely linear, ONLY 5 LEVELS, and they are charging 17.99 for a game that clearly hasn't been quality checked in terms of English, UI, control mapping, etc. Jump was mapped to B? 
This is garbage.

Unless you know what the hell Touhou is (I don't), this game makes ZERO effort to explain or introduce you to the world or lore. It just assumes you have had the time to research into whatever this Touhou stuff is, and if you haven't - too bad. Zero accessibility in terms of picking this game up without having looked at other titles. The English translations for both dialogue AND very important tutorial instructions are riddled with typos and grammatical errors that make understanding the game mechanics basically impossible. Did I mention apparently this only has 5 levels? I also read that they rolled out a DLC boss after selling out to Microsoft, but only made it available for consoles, and NOT on Steam. Sounds like a sell-out scam to me. 

If you are a fan of whatever franchise this is.....maybe you might like it? 
But if you like real metroidvanias......do not buy this. It is not a metroidvania and it is not a quality game. Sorry to Team Ladybug......but you cannot expect me to pay 17.99 for a game and then not even hire an editor for the English. 
0/10 do not recommend. If you want a bullet hell metroidvania that is similar in visual style but actually has a lot of content and isn't falsely advertised as a metroidvania, look at Rabi-Ribi and the sequel Tevi that will be coming out soon. I didn't expect to like that game, but it was actually amazing. This game however, is not.

148569215.review:
TL;DR: This is possibly my favorite metroidvania of all time, one of the most delightful gameplay experiences I've ever had. [b]S[/b].

It's definitely one of those games that's short but sweet, but that's not a bad thing by any means. Touhou Luna Nights isn't my first endeavor the world of Zun's bullet-hell series, but it's certainly the most unique one I've had so far. It should be prefaced that Luna Nights is a fangame, but an incredibly polished on that stands in its own right as one of the greatest metroidvania games ever created.

Luna Nights really shines in its gameplay. You play as Sakuya Izayoi, the time-manipulating maid from Touhou 6. Your primary tools are thrown knives and the previously mentioned power to stop time. I've never seen a game use the ability to stop time in quite the same way, but it's somewhat comparable to SUPERHOT if you have experience with that series. The game features the graze mechanic from the original Touhou games that allows you to regain resources but with a twist: grazing in stopped time doesn't recover your health, only your MP and time gauge. This makes every battle, but particularly the game's 5 or so bosses, a dance of risk vs. reward. If you can dodge the bullet-hell-like attack patterns without stopping time you can regain a significant amount of HP, but you can always stop time, which freeze most projectiles, to play it safe. I love the gameplay in Luna Nights and it's far and away my favorite metroidvania (maybe even game in general honestly) in this regard. Easily a 10/10, something truly unique.

The story is passable but not particularly compelling. You'll need a cursory knowledge of the Touhou franchise of you want to follow along, but I'd recommend you play Embodiment of Scarlet Devil first if you want to really understand everything. It isn't that it's that complicated, just that many characters from that game appear and it's cool to be able to see the characters from the original game brought to life in Luna Night's beautiful pixel-art style. Honestly, I think the story gets a 3.5/5, it isn't bad, but boring and the stakes are practically negligible. 

The art is fantastic. Even with, in some cases, hundreds of projectiles on screen you can clearly see what's going on. The game has a sort of chibi style to the characters, which is charming and sets it apart from other games o this type. The UI design is absolutely amazing, and it has such a distinct style to it that I love. Easy 5/5 here, it isn't my favorite game from a visual perspective but there isn't anything in particular that I don't actively like, it is perfect for what it is.

The music goes very hard. 5/5, this game somehow managed to improve on Touhou 6's soundtrack in some places.

All in all, 23.5/25, 94%, the game gets an [b]S[/b] ranking. Go play it if you haven't already, even if you're not a fan of the Touhou series this game is amazing. Even at full price this is a buy.

148428742.review:
This game has its flaws, and it feels like there was more planned than the dev was able to do. For example, there's a line about equipment, but there's no equipment system; and though all the gems list attribute-related effects they allegedly provide, they don't actually do anything except give you something to sell. Leveling up also doesn't appear to do anything; it certainly doesn't increase Sakuya's HP, MP, Time, or attributes. Enemy variety is a bit limited, but that's counterbalanced pretty well by the size of the map and number of areas to explore; this is a bite-sized Metroidvania, not a full-sized one.

The bosses tend to overstay their welcomes, in my opinion, but that's not to say they aren't impressive; they just have entirely too much health for my taste. Most of the time, a boss doesn't start using a new attack until halfway through her health bar, and maybe starts tossing out another new one after that about 3/4 of the way through; this leaves each fight feeling tedious and repetitive, in contrast to the way bosses' attack patterns flow smoothly from one to the next in official titles. Obviously, Luna Nights isn't a bullet hell, it's a Metroidvania—but it could have maintained that same smooth flow by knocking off a hefty chunk of each boss's total health. That being said, the boss themes are faithful and high-quality remixes of the originals, and the bosses' attack patterns themselves are quite a treat for the eyes, not to mention a pretty stimulating challenge to evade the first couple of times you see them.

The controls have a few irregularities, too. Double-jumping has an inexplicable inconsistency in its height; occasionally, you'll have to try the same jump a second or third time, even though the height you're starting from hasn't changed, just to get enough height to reach a platform. More commonly, you'll find Sakuya refusing to turn in the right direction, getting hit from behind while flinging knives at nothing. Both of these issues crop up just often enough to be noticed and yet rarely enough not to make the game significantly harder than it needs to be.

Despite these flaws, it generally feels good to play. The animation is smooth and detailed, the sprite work and backgrounds are both top-notch, the levels don't go overboard on time puzzles, and aside from a certain palpable over-reliance on selectively-intangible floating enemies in one particular area, even the individual rooms feel distinct and interesting.

This isn't the greatest Metroidvania ever made, nor the greatest Touhou spin-off ever made, but it is a fun and fairly well-polished budget game. Sadly, beating it won't stop weird nerds from calling you a secondary.

147649774.review:
A fantastic game. Short and sweet in its epitome. Fantastic design, cool mechanics, great music, etc. The bullet hell elements are fantastically done, and this is one of a small handful of games that really scratched my abnormally fickle bullet hell itch. The only problem I have gameplay wise is that nonessential upgrades are near universally hidden behind pretty arbitrary breakable walls. You get used to plinking around looking for them eventually, but it's not exactly compelling to me.

That all said, while it seems there's some incentive to play through a second time, a 5 hour runtime on a first playthrough makes it a touch of a hard sell to those looking for maximum time waste for cost. What's offered is so good, however, that I'd heartily recommend it to anybody needing to add some color back into their gaming addiction.

146617937.review:
I will with caution recommend it, if it's on sale. The biggest issue is it's just really short. Actual in game time was a bit less than five hours to beat the main game, and bonus stage, and 98% the map (just one spot that I know where it is, but don't care enough to go back to given how annoying level traversing can be here).
So if you want a game you could beat in a day, or two, this might be it. For the cost they ask, not really worth it, if it's on a 50% off sale or something, and you want touho metroidvania then ok though.

Onto the game itself. Core gameplay is... ok, decent at times, though has it's issues. It's a very button spammy game, so tying your fingers up on the controls can happen, and the default controls caused me quite a few mistakes/confusions given how they are setup. But after playing it I can see why they chose that... still, relearning control norms for such a short game gives me mixed feelings.
Well, at it's core the combat is decent, sometimes very good, othertimes quite slow. There's only a few bosses, they tend to be decently interesting to fight, but also most of them are just kind of easy. Though the bonus stage final boss is a decent challenge, worth maybe an hour. The second "final boss" I ended up beating fully on my first run, without any deaths for example. Even though it was a later on one.
The boss fights are honestly where this game is at it's best, though the problem is there aren't a lot of them, and it's padded out with a lot of slow map exploration. Many areas are slow, with time wasting mechanics where you must wait for X or Y to finish or circle around to move on, so some parts take minutes to get around just because of that, and if you die... you respawn back and must come back through it all again... 
General map exploration was the most annoying part of this game, at multiple points I kid of dreaded having to explore or progress through the world just because it was often more annoying or frustrating than fun or challenging to me.
So I had decent fun on most bosses, but just a meh experience in the world itself.
I would rate it on the lower end for a metroidvania overall, but the bosses and core combat when actually usable in some of those boss fights was at time very good. And while standing at a sharp contrast to other general gameplay mediocrity or even lackluster parts. So because of those few key moments and boss fights in the game I do feel I want to recomend it, there's some great moments there, but overall it will be diffused by a not great world and exploration, and just being a frankly very short experience. $20 for 5 hours of play (my timer says 6, I AFKd in game at some points to do other things) is pretty steep feeling, since it wasn't all the best of the best or anything. So my thoughts are, when on sale, give it a go. There is gold here, but only a bit mixed in with the rest, but still worth checking out for that.

For the developers, a decent attempt, but ya it just felt like it needed more. And making the world itself a bit more enjoyable or faster to navigate through, with fewer slow annoying gears and traps and barely moving platforms between save points, the better. The core combat on bosses is solid enough that if you focus on that, I'm sure you could definintely make another game with hopefully a bit more budget and thus content to really make something I'd love, but for now it's just got that mixed feeling, but hey, there are those great moments in it that still put it above most other random games by a decent bit, so take pride in that.

Finally, bugs. Found a few here and there, jump when near a ledge/edge doesn't seem reliable, even if not far enough to fall, but still towards the edge jump doesn't seem to activate reliably, or in a few other cases. If something outside of the game force tabs/focuses you out of it, then the resolution/screen size breaks and you just have a super tiny window in the center of the screen, that you basically need to restart to fix. And (minor spoiler warning) Remilias third phase with her final dialogue and then moves around 20% health left doesn't always trigger. First time I beat her, she never activated it for some reason. Few other mostly more minor bits that I've mostly forgotten as unimportant while/after playing.

Phenomenal Metroidvania game. Short, but hits all the right spots and I already want to get 100% then play it all over again. Never has stopping and slowing time felt so satisfying!

There's enough interesting abilities to allow even inexperienced players to comfortably beat the game [i]and[/i] have a lot of fun doing so! However, if you don't want to use said abilities the game still offers a fair challenge for experts. 

I thought the large number of spells available was kind of redundant at first, but the more I played the more I realised how useful all of them are in different situations, it's clear that a lot of thought was put into balancing and all that.

Get it if you're looking for a nice challenging experience for a weekend and beyond. You won't regret it.

143518364.review:
[h1] S Tier Metroidvania [/h1]

What a surprise this was.
I was holding on this game for so long, and that was a mistake.
It's such a polished, innovative experience that doesn't overstay its welcome.

Why is that:
[list]
    [*]Very pleasing graphicswise, great spritework
    [*]Catchy OST
    [*]Clean and cool looking UI
    [*]Time stop and slow mechanic which provides great proactive gameplay in and out of combat
    [*]Difficulty feels just right (on the easier side, very few spikes)
[/list]

I have criticism for only two things:
[list]
    [*]The game is pretty short.
    [*]The map is relatively simple and small, not much in terms of interconnection of levels.
[/list]
I didn't mind it being on the simpler side, but I had to mention these.

Basically I can recommend this game to everyone who likes the genre.

143473605.review:
One of the best Touhou fangames and probably one of the best Metroidvanias you can buy here on Steam. Takes inspiration from the Castlevania side more and the combat system does share a couple similarities with Order of Ecclesia. Overall presentation is fantastic. You also don't need to be familiar with the official games/characters to enjoy the game.

Game controls wonderfully and your abilities will be put to use not only for combat and traversal, but puzzle solving as well. Sakuya has the ability to temporarily stop time around her to graze for resources, dish out damage, and to move to a more desirable location. It's required for some puzzles, but for bosses and other combat scenarios it's entirely optional. For your first playthrough, be sure to utilize it, but after that, use it less and less or even avoid using it all together to challenge yourself if you wish. You won't be having a lesser experience if you rely on time stop as there is a satisfying gameplay loop with it and there is a limit to how much you can use it. The power-ups you can collect are really cool additions to your tool set too with some familiar moves with a new twist, like the double jump that also fires knives underneath you, or something entirely new, such as the ability to use your thrown knives as platforms while time is stopped (which is honestly one of the coolest abilities I've seen in a Metroidvania so far).

The bosses are a highlight for sure. All being faces mostly from Touhou 6: The Embodiment of Scarlet Devil. They are represented really well here through their dialogue, animation, and fights. Quite a few of their attacks are also derived from their fights in the official games, but redesigned to fit the new game genre. Even with the ability to stop and slow down time, they can make short work of you if you aren't careful so you are likely to lose to each of them a couple times before you finally take them down. The true final boss took me multiple attempts to beat, but to be fair to myself, I somehow arrived underleveled so that's on me. If you find yourself struggling too much for your liking, enemies drop gems on death which you can trade for things like full HP/MP restores, time stop upgrades, instant level-ups, etc. Though you are rewarded for hanging on to them as they improve your stats slightly; it won't be much at first, yeah, but it does add up over time.

Last subject I better focus on is the game's shortcomings. While I do enjoy most of the abilities you gain in the game, I wish there were more of them; a good chunk of things you'll find for progression just open new kinds of doors. Backtracking can be a pain if you need to get through a puzzle or platforming challenge you've already done before. And, while this isn't a huge deal for myself, you can finish the game in about 4 hours and I was able to collect all achievements within 10. I think I'd rather have a shorter game with some good ideas rather than a longer game that overstays its welcome. Regardless, I feel I still need to mention this.

tl;dr - Do not need to be familiar with source material to enjoy. Fantastic gameplay and bosses with cool abilities utilized in all sorts of ways (combat, traversal, puzzles, accessibility). Though it's on the shorter side and some instances of backtracking could require redoing platforming challenges/puzzles. Overall phenomenal Metroidvania.

141501783.review:
I think it's safe to say that you know a game is special when just its opening moments alone cause you to become infatuated with the developer itself; such is the case with Team Ladybug's wonderful Touhou Luna nights from 2019, the first commercial title from the small Japanese team.

The moment the game starts, you are assaulted with some truly beautiful pixel art and charming character animation, only to then be really shaken by its first special moment: a fast revolving door blocking the way forward, inciting the player to use one of its special mechanics to slow the flow of time and pass through just before the next door comes around to block you again. If this moment excited you even slightly, you would be oh-so unprepared for the constant stream of excellent game design that follows.

The game's world and characters are based on ZUN's longrunning Touhou series of danmaku shooter titles, which definitely docks some points for originality. While undeniably charming, the story itself is nothing more than a series of clichés and references, with a general humorous tone that helps alleviate a bit of the derivativeness. You play as Sakuya Izayoi, a maid summoned to another dimension by a vampire named Remilia Scarlet, who takes away your ablities in the process. What follows is a journey to regain your power, as well as finding a way back to her world. That being said, a deep yearning to achieve some seriously original game design can be felt strongly throughout.

Sakuya's main method of attack is throwing knives forward or downward diagonally when jumping. This attack is tied to a magic bar. When a knife is thrown, magic is consumed. Beginner players will most likely find themselves regularly depleting their magic bar, unable to throw any more knives. It's rather unusual of a explorative 2D action game like this to restrict your fundamental, and so far, only method of attack. The magic bar does refill itself, albeit very slowly. Shortly after you meet the game's merchant character Nitori, who also gives you a powerup allowing you to stop time completely, and this is where the game becomes truly magical.

While time is stopped, all enemies cease moving and Sakuya is able to navigate the screen without a care, and more importantly, position a limited number of frozen knives in front of enemies, which is what really separates this game's time-stopping mechanic from other games. The fun of suddenly stopping everything and then positioning knives tactically in front of different enemies, even in different directions, is bliss beyond words. Then, upon restarting the flow of time or exhausting the newly required time unit found in the center of the HUD, you get you to witness your enemies suddenly terminate before your eyes. Besides simply being a more efficient means of offense, the time stopping mechanic also allows you to "graze" enemies, by getting very close to them without making contact. Doing this draws in pink cards from them, refilling your magic bar, another moment guaranteed to widen the initial smile on your face.

Once becoming accustomed to the constant dance of stopping time regularly to set up attacks, and graze nearby enemies to refill the required energy to do so, you've understood the flow of gameplay. It should also be noted that the grazing mechanic also works in real-time (accordingly more difficult to perform) but works as a method to refill your health bar instead. This mechanic is actually lifted from the main Touhou titles, but I would argue that it feels so much more special than a simple nod to the source material given how beautifully it was conceived and implemented in this game. Not being content with underutilizing the mechanic, the developers also provide sparse puzzles in certain rooms, which challenge you to pause for a moment to consider how you can use your aforementioned time slowing, along with the time stopping in order to get through unscathed. They also smartly introduce obstacles that play with established conventions, like platforms and enemies that move even in stopped time. It's really brilliant how the mechanics are gradually introduced, and then layered on top of one another. This is something I wish the game had more of, but what is here is still interesting.

I've almost forgotten that this game is also advertised and regarded as a "Metroidvania" title. It's true, many of the staples of the genre are here and accounted for: the map system revealing the rooms you've found, the color-coded areas, and of course, the secret rooms. Though, I've seen many reviewers are players alike criticise how linear this game is compared to its peers. The game is surprisingly less open-ended than one would initially assume, with usually only a few multiple paths at a given time, often linking up to each other, and plenty of colored doors blocking you until you get the appropriate key. I do not find this design detrimental to the game in the slightest. In fact, I would go as far as to say it doesn't matter what players expect a "genre" to be, and I applaud it for breaking convention with a more linear approach, while maintaining some exploration. It's the best of both worlds: players who like exploration can search for the inessential powerups and players who would prefer to view the game as a more traditional 2D action platformer can do so. I prefer to view it as the latter.

When it comes to my gripes regarding the game, I would start with the level mechanic. Much like in the Koji Igarashi produced Castlevania titles, you gain experience when defeating enemies and your stats increase throughout as you progress. Given that I prefer the more focused action portion of the game, I feel like this was an unneeded feature. Thankfully, unlike many other titles, it never really feels overpowered. The game only slightly powers you up, and the enemies constantly grow in strength and numbers (which can get frustrating in some rooms it you lack patience). Ultimately, I would much prefer if the game didn't include such a system, and just focused on the core gameplay which is so good. There are also various special abilities which consume a greater amount of magic. Many of these are useful in the different situations, but they are all outperformed by a single ability called Thousand Dagger. This ability is so ridiculously efficient and powerful, it effectively diminishes the game's brilliance if overused. I wish the developers retooled this one some more.

Separating the game's main areas are the fantastic bosses, featuring a great cast of stylish characters. These fights do a fantastic job of incorporating great action, as well as the game's puzzle elements when trying to figure out how to avoid some of the bosses' seriously intimidating attack patterns. The developers knew these bosses stole the show, as a boss rush mode is included after clearing the game. Unfortunately, the boss rush is a ridiculously easy due to the fact that you maintain the levels and abilities obtained throughout your playthrough. All-in-all, an absolutely fantastic 2D action game that begs to be replayed, with mechanics that truly captivated me.

[b]Rating: 7.5/10[/b]

141274145.review:
To be transparent, one of the BEST metroidvania/platformer titles anyone can play. Time manipulation is implemented EXTREMELY well when it comes to the platforming and combat of the game. So many unique ways such as water being turning solid when time is stopped, and objects/enemies having certain properties that can change their behavior around time stopping. Examples would include ignoring, being in reverse, or only moving when time is stopped. 

Combining both time slow and stop makes for interesting gameplay where some players can choose to slip through and dance through tough areas or scrap their way out using the tools at their arsenal. Either way, both ways of progression lead to satisfaction due to how areas are designed to not be easily overpowered by the mechanic of time manipulation. 

Progression feels very nice to go through and experience, bosses allow for mass amounts of creativity of how to approach them, leading to different playstyles and trying out strategies to eventually overcome and be rewarded by the satisfaction of learning the patterns and how to respond to the attacks. Eventually you weave and slide in a dance with the bosses to take them out, and it's truly beautiful. Though I will say some enemies seem to have stacked as heck health nearing the end of the game which is a little tedious. On the note of that the game isn't too long, cracking down in maybe around 4 hours but the replayability value of the game is pretty good. 

TLDR: VERY GOOD METROIDVANIA worth picking up if you're a metroidvania fanatic or someone looking for a game featuring the world of Touhou to enjoy. 

also sakuya's bizarre adventure funny haha.

139407917.review:
Folks, let me tell you about this amazing game, Touhou Luna Nights. It's a true masterpiece, believe me. This game takes the bullet hell genre to new heights, like you've never seen before. It's tremendous, folks, simply tremendous.

Now, this game is heavily inspired by the Touhou series, which is a fantastic Japanese franchise known for its cute girls and intense bullet patterns. Touhou Luna Nights captures that essence perfectly, just like I capture ratings in the polls. It's got the charm, the action, and the memes, believe me.

When you step into the shoes of Sakuya Izayoi, the maid from the Scarlet Devil Mansion, you know you're in for a treat. The game throws wave after wave of beautifully crafted bullets at you, making your heart race faster than a politician on the campaign trail. The sheer challenge is like negotiating a trade deal with China. You've got to dodge, weave, and time your moves perfectly, just like I do when facing the media.

But here's the best part, folks: the time-stop mechanic. Sakuya has the power to manipulate time, just like I have the power to make America great again. With this ability, you can freeze enemies and projectiles, turning the battlefield into your own personal dance floor. It's like holding a rally with thousands of supporters cheering you on.

The graphics in Touhou Luna Nights are beautiful, folks. The pixel art style is like a fine piece of art hanging in the Trump Tower. The attention to detail is tremendous, and the characters are so cute, it's almost like they're real. I'd love to have a few of them as campaign advisers, believe me.

And let's not forget the music, folks. The soundtrack is catchy and energetic, just like my speeches. It keeps you pumped up and ready for action. When the boss battles kick in, it's like facing off against Crooked Hillary herself. It's intense, it's exhilarating, and it's what makes this game so special.

Now, some people may say that Touhou Luna Nights is a niche game, but let me tell you, folks, it's for winners. It's for those who appreciate skill, strategy, and a touch of madness. If you're a fan of Touhou, bullet hell games, or just good old-fashioned fun, this game is a must-play.

In conclusion, Touhou Luna Nights is a tremendous experience, folks. It's got the challenge, the charm, and the memes that will make you feel like a winner. So grab your keyboard, fire up your PC, and get ready to show those bullets who's boss. This game gets my highest rating, just like I got the highest ratings in the history of ratings. Play it, folks, and make bullet hell great again!

136750934.review:
[h1]PEAK GAMING[/h1]


I've played a grand total of three (3) metroidvanias in my life (none of which were a Metroid or a Vania) so I cannot speak at length about how this one compares to its contemporaries or to its great primogenitors (such as Super Metroid or Symphony of the Night), but I gotta say it's a [b]damn[/b] fine game in a vacuum. 

It's neither (i) overly long nor (ii) too difficult, it's (iii) real fun, it's got a (iv) fantastic presentation, and it's a (v) heartfelt homage to Touhou.

Play it. Pray to it. Give the shrine maiden your money.


(i) - It takes 5-or-so hours to finish, up to 15 to platinum. Coming from a 100-hour-long visual novel series and Monster Hunter, I am [i]incredibly[/i] thankful for such a merciful runtime.

(ii) - I cannot recall a time prior to the Extra Stage when I had any major difficulty with the stages or the bosses, so I - as someone  - will allow myself to be so bold as to say that this game's not too mean so long as you take full advantage of its mechanics... which does not sound helpful in the slightest, does it? 
[quote=my stupid ass]uhm actually the bideo gane's not hard when you know how to play the bideo gane[/quote]

(iii) - Time manipulation is a ton of fun. It's a well-executed core mechanic that ostensibly lets [b]you[/b] dictate the pace of your battles. You're even rewarded for not relying on it too much with greater grazing bonuses. Speaking of, [i]grazing[/i] or narrowly avoiding projectiles makes its way into this game from the traditional Touhou shmups which is nice. Grazing translates to MP which you need to perform an attack, special or otherwise. This works well because it encourages you to get into the thick of an enemy's attack and turn the tables on them. It's a much more exciting flow of things than gluing yourself to the edge of the arena and waiting for your MP to recharge.
Bosses (which are the entire cast of EotSD minus Koakuma and Rumia) can be tough, but none of them had me dreading fighting them again and again in Boss Rush mode. They're a joy to fight, the lot of them. I suppose it is precisely [i]because[/i] the game is so focused that their fights are polished to a mirror sheen.

(iv) - The pixel art and animations are very nice to look at, but the music's the real star of the show. They're all remixes of tracks from the shmups and they're all [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cWITITpjA8s]fan[/url][url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g39jVVyCVVM]tas[/url][url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1cjGITlCdw0]tic[/url].

(v) - I just ain't built for shmups so my affinity for Touhou mostly stems from its music, the gajillions of illustrations inspired by its zany characters, and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q16KpquGsIc]that one insane YTPMV feat. Ronald McDonald[/url]. Despite my vicarious enjoyment of it, Team Ladybug's love for the source material in this project is palpable even to someone like me.

135018916.review:
2d metroidvania where the unique feature is that you can slow or stop time

using the time controls took a bit to get used to, but once I did, I really appreciated how the game designers integrated this so it feels like a natural part of the game and not just a gimmick. you'll need to master them to beat all of the bosses and find 100% of the collectibles

the leveling system is really well balanced, I collected enough EXP naturally while exploring that I only felt like I really needed to grind to get a better rank in the boss rush at the very end of the game, but I also didn't level up so much naturally that it made the boss fights too easy

the boss fights are definitely challenging but not unfairly so. you'll probably die a few times on each before you figure out the patterns well enough to counter

I'm the type of person who will just about always try to find 100% of the collectibles anyway, but this game makes that exploration process fun, unlike some games where it kind of feels like a chore to find those last few items. if you're alert you'll probably find at least 3/4 of them naturally while exploring, and near the end of the game you pick up an item that makes it easy to find the rest

I haven't played any of the other Touhou games, but was able to appreciate the story in this one without feeling like I was missing out on some context from another game

overall, great game. would definitely recommend

134520280.review:
It's a metroidvania with what you'd expect:
- starting with nothing and getting more powerful as you collect more items
- there's plenty of hidden items to collect
- while there are keys and locked doors, a lot of areas require discovered abilities to traverse through
- you play in a large map that you're allowed to freely roam around in so long as you have the abilities and keys to progress

Pros:
+ timestop and timeslow are fun to use
+ the platforming puzzles are enjoyable
+ challenging boss fights that make use of game mechanics you previously learned
+ great art, music, and sounds
+ feels good to control
+ the warp rooms are much appreciated

Neutral:
* a fairly short game. While the game is quality which I'll take over quantity, this has to be mentioned. For reference, I beat the game, including it's postgame stage at around 4 to 5 hours.
* somewhat linear in that you beat stage 2's boss to gain access to stage 3, beat that boss to get to stage 4, etc etc. I don't think this is a flaw, I'm just mentioning it. There's still multiple rooms to choose from in each stage to be clear.

Cons:
- the map could have been a little more helpful with item locations in areas you've explored. Even a Super Metroid dot would have sufficed to reduce the amount of wandering around to find that one wooden box.
- I felt like I was being punished when I unlocked the ability to reach higher locations and backtracked to an earlier unreachable area to see what I'd find. Just before reaching it, you have to get through a slog of platform puzzles that take a while and there's a save room right after. Turns out I reached that new area only to be greeted with a locked door. I had to then slog through the platform puzzle rooms again because i already saved in that area. If there was at least an item to pickup there, it would have felt rewarding.

Overall I had a fun experience playing this game. You don't need to be a Touhou fan to enjoy it.

132139523.review:
Absolute banger of a game, would highly recommend, not much to say so here are my thoughts:

The Bad:

Control:  
What the hell are the default controls, this took me a while to get my head around, lucky you can re-bind them but through half the experience i felt i was fighting the game itself and not just the enemies.

Length of the game: 
the game is incredibly short and doesn't take too long to master, its something you can pick up and beat in a weekend and still be hooked on the game wanting more, its bonus stage does add to this a bit more but it just doesn't feel like its enough...

Replayability:
other than going for the 0 deaths achievement i don't see too much replay value, even despite the amazing quality of the game itself.

Story: 
Assuming you know nothing about Touhou, you will likely have no idea what is going on or who the characters are, it mainly revolves around the ESoD cast with the only outlier being Nitori , meaning the main story may be hard to follow with jokes and gags that will fly over a newer fans head.


The Good
 
great fights: 
from the random skeletons to the bosses themselves they all bring an interesting and unique challenge that really captures the world they are apart of (ignoring the bloody minigun fairies), the only boss fight that i felt was really lacking in difficulty was patchouli's fight, i wont say much here to avoid spoilers but her second phase just doesn't feel like it brings enough to the table.

Amazing music:
after all, almost all the Touhou tracks are brilliant, but the luna nights remixes for the most part feels like a step up, even despite almost all of the ost being only ESoD remixes.

Secrets:
This game hides a lot of Secrets: abilities, gems, collectables, and even an entire bonus stage you have to go out of your way to find, it truly does add  a lot to world the game takes place in.

Art
i don't know what the devs were smoking, but i want some! i absolutely adore games that are built around pixel art, but this game feels perfect; from the sprites to the backgrounds, everything is on-point, and on top of that the animations are clean and smooth. 

A LOT of effort has gone into to this game, and it has paid off, it is an amazing game i would highly recommend.

De entre tantas excentricidades que este rabbit hole llamado Touhou Project alberga, Touhou Luna Nights es uno de los fangames más destacables en el catálogo de Steam, tratándose de un metroidvania de estética pixelada y anime cuya banda sonora se conforma por remixes de canciones clásicas de la franquicia.

Artísticamente es brillante, es divertido explorar el mapa, compensa la curiosidad del jugador y el combate es muy responsivo y gratificante. Touhou Luna Nights es un juego excelente y muy carismático que sólo podría haber sido creada por integrantes de esta subcultura.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Excelente juego.

130890306.review:
I get the appeal but "pausing" time to get in attacks is not for me because it interrupts the flow of combat. Feels kinda clunky to use mid battle. 

It's weird that you have two time control mechanics: the first one you have to hold a button just to slow time while other one instantly happens after a button press and completely freezes time so it's easy to see which is the superior one and which one is instantly obsolete and limited mostly to environmental puzzles. 

Also, I don't get why other players say that this game is better than Deedlit. I enjoyed Deedlit just from the start but this one, just doesn't appeal to me.

So anyways, if interrupting the game just to get attacks appeals to you then get this game. If you want a more real time twitch reaction type of combat with a variety of melee weapons and ranged combat then Deelit is the superior one.

129885671.review:
Touhou Luna Nights isn't for everyone, by which I mean if you are looking for an intricate interconnected metroidvania world, you won't get it here. But it has a great level of a casual accessible fun-filled flair to it with still a memorable challenge. It should first be noted this a fangame of the popular bullet hell series and general world Touhou and is centered around the character Sakuya Izayoi, who is one of my favorites. A lot of the positive reviews are likely from fans. 

But that alone I don't think accounts for it-I see this game in tops in same metroidvania spheres in terms of boss fights, I see multiple well praising critics. Sometimes a game gets overwhelmingly positive reviews for being just so refined at every level (for instance, Hollow Knight). This... isn't one of them I'd say.

The levels aren't great, art is bland at times, it is the most primitive form of a metroidvania and is very linear, the movement isn't wholly concordant with the levels, the lore is nonexistent, and the game is very short. But somehow none of that really matters. If that were a central focus, a more involved intricate exploratory game, then there would be problems. But somehow framing the game as more simple minded but interesting fun makes it perfect for its purpose.

It's like a fun gimmick game on the XBox store which is there for a good time rather than dedicate all your focus on.

CENTRAL GAMEPLAY

That central gimmick is time manipulation. Now now, time manipulation is up there in 'have run out of ideas' sphere. But it makes sense with this character and is utilized beautifully.

There are 3 meters: health, mana, and time. Health is well health. Mana is used in normal mode to use all your weapons. You can use special weapons which require more. Mana replenishes slowly.

You can slow down time-this is not the same as stopping time and does not use your time meter. When time is slowed, things move slower but you move same speed. This helps you dodge but nothing fundamentally about the game
has changed so I'll still count it as  'normal mode'.

You can also stop time. This uses up you time meter slowly depending on how long you've used it. It is spent faster the more you move. Additionally, in this mode, doing attacks uses time but not mana. When in normal mode, time replenishes
by itself quickly.

The final piece of this puzzle is grazing. In Touhou, grazing is when you go near bullets, which helps give you points. In this game, it helps replenish mana, time, and health. When you are in normal mode, grazing gives you just health. When you are in time stop, it gives you primarily mana and time although some amount of health I think. What this means is you generally need to utilize time slow to help yourself heal by dodging, need to keep a steady time meter so you can use it to refill your mana which is drained quickly and dodge attacks, and need to keep steady mana so you have other attacks to go off of so you don't use too much time so you use time.

So it is wonderfully balanced and dynamic system, and the game is about able to keep these in balance. At first, it has this very interesting feeling of a 'stop and go' playstyle-it helps give you time to sort out all your options and almost like a dynamic puzzle, figure out what to do. Where to dodge, how to attack, how to balance your meters, etc. and makes it the closest to a strategy metroidvania. But, as you get familiar, it feels more fluid and natural-like you know what attack is coming up and so these are just another mechanical tool to switch between.

The movement on the whole feels fluid and nice and well matching with the time controls especially in gathered abilities later.

BOSSES

The boss fights are a particular highlight and frankly some of the best I've seen, making clever use of both the time slow and time stop mechanics and with a generally coherently yet distinctive felt series of abilities that make sense with their character. It never feels like just a different string of the same attacks, that each character is offering something new. Now, a difficulty with talking about memorability is bosses is at first they're hard-then you learn them and then it feels 'simple'. But judging as a whole, I think it still feels fluid and well designed even after you know them. And, I really love the boss rush mode. Because the nature of this game seems to boil down to 'optimizing', making it about getting your time of beating them down is great and adds a whole other layer. Because time stop slows down the game, you can start asking of how you play without it. There is thus more replayability in that area I'd feel and I feel I'll come to it again.

ART AND MUSIC

Visually, the game has this soft pixel-art feel with an overall great composition. There are various points though where it is particularly bland, or has bad edges (basically all of stage 1s design including the enemies, most of the rest of the areas feel really nice though). Sometimes enemy design is a bit clashing but on the whole lots of it is good. The music naturally borrows the renowned melodies of the character theme songs in the Touhou franchise made by ZUN and puts it in a kind of castlevania feel, it has this 'soft pixely' feel that fits very well with the art that makes it feel distinctive and fitting.

LEVELS

Now, when in comparison to lots of the real great forms of level design in other games, it may begin to feel normalized and numb to. So it's hard to tell difference between good and average. Here, the level design doesn't feel the greatest at times. Sometimes it's too flat, sometimes it's too many pointless corridors not designed with your movement nor attacks in mind, there is lots of negative space. There are some interesting platforming sections making use of your time ability that I like, although I do wish it were more 'integrated' in a room rather than feeling like just a series of obstacles stringed together. When you get more abilities, few levels seem designed with it in mind-for instance, the dash. I think a lot more coherent movement+diverse enemy+level design would have greatly helped. The world design also suffers a bit, having many one-off areas, not the greatest teleportation hubs. On the whole though, to me it's fine enough. It's nothing game ruining. It's average and good. It is well varied and never overstays its welcome. 

EXPLORATION

And of course, on the metroidvania front, I mentioned it's very primitive. Often you encounter something, check other unexplored area, its exactly what you need and is a dead end, and all you can go is go back. So, maybe it doesn't wholly feel in some areas (especially stage 1) that there is a world to support what is often one boss fight right after the next. This will make the game feel especially short, given the few boss fights, and may leave you wanting more.

FINAL THOUGHTS

So, given all the positives and the numerous flaws, would I recommend? Well, I beat the main game very quickly, maybe in 6 hours, and all bosses 10 hours in. I got all the items 16 hours which was just routine 'check hidden wall' maintenance and other trivial tasks. Yet, somehow it never felt boring and I feel like I'll want to revisit. The fluid gameplay, top tier bosses, interesting mechanic, just nice feeling art and music, and more simple minded fun kind of atmosphere made it one of my favorite gaming experiences yet. I do wish there was a bit more there in some areas because I truly do think it could go *a lot* further. (Hollow Knight probably spoiled me)

But let me put it this way-another game I played was Guacamelee-it probably had some of the better levels, enemies, and world. Yet, I didn't care at all to 100% that one. It felt too blocky and not interesting enough in gameplay for me, the bosses meddling good. This game in its simple minded fun gets through with fine enough level and world and focuses its efforts on one very interesting, great feeling gameplay.

I bought this as part of the Team Ladybug Bundle and while all three games ultimately disappointed me, this one is by far the worst. 
Just like Humpty Dumpty in Wonder Showzen or whatever it is called, Luna Nights ruins a unique and interesting spin on a 2D Metroidvania with really, REALLY awful level design. Here it's just pure, uncompromising garbage right from the get go. So at least I only wasted my money on this one and not particularly much of my time. Touhou Luna Nights is an incredible metroidvania that is about 7 hours long. The final 2 hours being a bonus stage they added later. I found those stages to be annoying but the two extra bosses to be a BIG deal.

The game has you playing as Sakuy a Izayoi, you have the ability to throw knives and stop time. They way time being stopped is genius as you will unlock the ability to use knives as platforms, run across water, and throw a ton of knives while the time is frozen and then unfreeze time killing people with a bunch of knives. There are water physics which can change things a bit when time is stopped and its really really good. The art style is beautiful, and the entire game I feel stays around perfectly, even though the final push for the purple key I found was super annoying to get to the final area, and that the extra stage was quite annoying and the big part of them were the two final bosses.

9.5/10 If you are a metroidvania fan absolutely play this, if you are a Touhou fan absolutely play this. If you are both, then you absolutely must play this.

126943983.review: A Metroidvania so focused in purpose and execution that it becomes an instant classic. It's short, but worth replaying multiple times. Tight level design, innovative and addicting combat and platforming, gorgeous art direction and sprite work, and an enchanting soundtrack which arguably improves on the original Touhou 6 OST in some places. Mixed in is the typical Touhou goodness, with funny and charming characters, dialogue, and difficult bullet-hell boss fights. Not a single fight stands out as weak, and falling into the rhythm is often one of the most satisfying feelings in gaming. All killer, no filler. This is Sakuya's essence distilled into one game, and you owe it to yourself to give it a try.

This is honestly a really good touhou game. It's a fan-game and not danmaku (well it has the tag but it's not mainly danmaku) This game plays like castlevania and metroid. Therefore the "Metroidvania" tag. Unfortunately the game is a little short but still enjoyable. 

In this game you play a woman called "Sakuya Izayoi" (In the main touhou games by ZUN the protagonists are Reimu and Marisa. They also appear in this game) and you are in a false, virtual dimension of the main place "Gensokyo" which is the land of touhou. This dimension is created by her mistress "Remilia Scarlet" which is another girl but unlike sakuya she isn't human and has wings ( She look very human though ). Now your objective is to clear the stages from the bad guys and sometimes interesting events happen. For example someome suddenly appears and then there is funny dialogue. Seriously sometimes i giggled from what they say in this game xD. Across the map you unlock many items that help you in your adventure. Sakuya has the ability to slow down time and even stop time. Durring a time stop you can throw your knifes. Does this sound familiar? Sakuya is literally like Dio from Jojo but female and a maid lol.
If you beat this game, there is still things to do. Just like in the official games you can enter a "Extra Stage" that includes an extra boss. If you Defeat that extra stage you also unlock a boss rush mode. And even after that, you can still do achievements. So if you want more of this game you can attempt getting all the achievements because then you did everything there is to do.

I recommend this game if you like:
1. Touhou
2. Time manipulation 
3. Metroidvania / Sidescroller
4. Maids
5. Touhou music or cool music in general

124428921.review:
Touhou Luna Nights is a game I would recommend... with caveats, as it's a game I almost dropped on a couple of occasions, though in the end I was happy I didn't.

The start is pretty weak, the first quarter or so of the game leaves you without good mobility options and neglects to interact with the core time manipulation mechanics, even. But once you get to the double jump, movement starts actually being enjoyable, and once the puzzle/trap sections start involving parts that actually react to time stops in ways other than "everything stops," you start having to think a bit. It's fun, and I really wish there'd have been more of that, it's probably what I enjoyed most of all.

A close second is the boss battles, which are all pretty great. My one complaint, if anything, is that a couple of them involve some patterns that are really finnicky to dodge(more on this in a bit) and one pattern that I literally could not comprehend how to get out of.

If there's anything I do absolutely loathe about Luna Nights, though, it's the Graze mechanic. If you get close enough to an enemy without being damaged by them, you get HP, MP, TP(Time Points) back. If you do this while timestopped, you only get MP and TP. The problem is that "close enough" is "literally inside their sprite," which contributes to hitboxes being baffling eldritch entities that I will not for the life of me ever comprehend in this game. Related, a couple of traps in the game(and one boss attack move) also involve "spirals" where part of the spiral goes into the background, other into the foreground, and I always felt it was hard to tell what parts I could safely dive through while timestopped/slowed.

In relation to that, Luna Nights also has some of the most aggressive knockback-on-hit damage of any platformer I've played. Sometimes it'll literally throw you into different screens entirely, and there are also a couple where the super finicky last jump, if you take a hit, means the knockback is liable to set you back all the way to the start of the screen.

Related to "setbacks," I have rarely seen a game with such actively malicious(or random? maybe it was just rolling a die to determine?) placement of save points, fast travel points and heal points. Not a single fast travel point is ALSO a save and/or heal point, and they often involve traversing multiple screens to get to those things. I would've loved to take a jab at finding all the secrets and a couple of other things, but hell no, it would've involved WAY too much super-unfun navigation to accomplish.

The map is also really bad at indicating where you need to return with upgrades to do things, not even marking locked doors. As far as I can tell there wasn't any way to mark areas, either.

Secondary abilities were also... bad, there were two I ever used(for their auto-aiming abilities) since Sakuya herself can really only attack up, left, right(there's no direct down attack, even) and some flying enemies love to hide inside walls/floors, the game could've used a bit more balancing in that regard.

And then there are... the RPG mechanics. They are bad. They are super bad. They are probably the worst thing about the game, especially since the game happily lets you screw yourself over by not explaining them until about halfway through. Essentially enemies drop stat boosting gems, that at first you are only told is money, but then after you've likely spent a bunch of them as money, you're explained that they're stat boosters.

Without collecting a lot of these you have no passive health regen, your passive mana regen is INSANELY slow, grazes are unrewarding and time points regenerate super slowly. So this can be a bit of a "fuck you" to the player at such a point in the game. And even then, if you want to collect enough of them to matter, you will need to grind literal HUNDREDS of enemies.

Without some severe rebalancing, the game would've been much better off just having a higher base damage, time/mana/HP regen and time pool.

Despite all these complaints, I am still recommending Luna Nights, because while there are things that don't work, and things that work badly... the developer clearly has good ideas. The mid/late-game puzzle areas often show fun, interesting and varied creativity, relying more on puzzle comprehension than puzzle execution(timing, reflexes) and once you have the double jump, the mobility really flows in a satisfying way.

Additionally the soundtrack(while being, admittedly, mostly arranges of Touhou themes) is really good and the sprite and background work are just amazing. Hats off to Patchy and Nitori in that regard especially, amazing stuff.

Do keep in mind the game is like... four or five hours long unless you really get stuck on a fight and need to grind or need to obsessively push through everything in the game.

122415926.review:
Are you a Touhou fan? Are you a Metroidvania fan? If you're one or both of these things, then Touhou Luna Nights might be the quick fix for you!

Since I'm more of a Touhou fan, I will speak more from that prospective. This game is the epitome of what the Touhou fan community can achieve (and I must stress that this is [b]a fan game[/b], not an official game). Even if you've never heard of Touhou or played an official Touhou game before, Luna Nights serves as a good standalone game or can serve as a great introduction to the series that has had a strong fan following for almost two decades now! If you've been on the internet long enough, then you've definitely listened to the classic pieces such as "U.N. Owen Was Her?" or the fanmade "Night of Nights" before and you get to listen to them again in this game, alongside many other Touhou songs!

The story is simple: Remilia creates a pocket dimension that is an exact copy of the Scarlet Devil Mansion to have some fun without causing any trouble in Gensokyo. Her maid Sakuya, the main character of the game, plays along (not that she's given a choice) by exploring the fake mansion, but eventually has to convince Remilia to return them to the real dimension. All other inhabitants of the real Scarlet Devil Mansion (except Koakuma) appear as bosses. Other Touhou characters that appear in the game are: Nitori, who sells items to Sakuya that can help her along the way; Akyuu, who records Sakuya's actions and acts the the game's primary save function; and Marisa, who is her own standalone boss alongside the Scarlet Devil Mansion inhabitants. The post-game segment also features Reimu and Cirno as their own separate bosses.

In terms of gameplay, Touhou Luna Nights is a Metroidvania platformer that incorporates bullet hell mechanics that Touhou fans that have played the official games are familiar with - namely the graze mechanic. In official Touhou games, grazing projectiles adds to your score. But in Touhou Luna Nights, grazing is important for regaining HP and MP, the later of which allows you to use different power-ups after finding them scattered throughout the mansion. And Sakuya's ability to manipulate time also paves the way to two different mechanics; freezing and slowing down time for a short while. These mechanics can help you solve puzzles and make fighting enemies and bosses easier, and you can increase the period that time will remain frozen as you progress through the game.

This game can get a little grindy the further you are to the end as enemies will get harder as you progress through the game. This is alleviated by the previously mentioned power-ups you find along the way and a level-up system. The more enemies you kill, the more XP you gain to level yourself up and get stronger. It will test you patience and I highly recommend that you kill all enemies you encounter early on if you can so that you don't have to grind as you get closer to the end.

There are two criticisms I have for this game though. One of them regards Cirno, one of the most popular and recognizable characters in the series. She wasn't originally in this game upon its initial release and it wasn't until 2020 when she was added as a boss. But it looks like your fight with her is the [i]only[/i] encounter you will have with her in that playthrough and save file. She doesn't even appear in the boss rush. If the developers ever come back to this game, I hope they will fix this oversight.

The other criticism is its length: it's too short. The story and post-game can be completed in approximately six hours. You'll have a lot of fun with this game, but it'll leave you wanting more content by the time you complete it.

But overall, Touhou Luna Nights is a fun little adventure filled with charming characters that fans are familiar with and first timers will learn to love, but its length leaves some things to be desired. I would love it if Team Ladybug made another Touhou fangame that explores another setting and features other characters in the Touhou universe.

9/10 - Great game and love letter to the Touhou Project, but it should be longer.

121807732.review:
A spectacular Metroidvania in every single way.

This is a Touhou fangame, in which you play as Sakuya Izayoi, the head maid of the Scarlet Devil Mansion. Sakuya's signature ability is stopping time, and this is your main tool throughout the game.

Gameplay is great - standard Metroidvania fare with the ability to stop time. All of your abilities are projectile-based, and in stopped time you can stack up a whole bunch of them and let them loose all at once. Incredibly satisfying.

The core of gameplay is also the "graze" mechanic. If you "near miss" a projectile or an enemy, coming close, but not close enough to actually get hit, you get health and ammo. This promotes fast, aggressive play - but because you can just STOP TIME, it never gets too hard. Frankly, it's a cakewalk even compared to mainline Touhou games - treat it as a more of a power fantasy than a challenge.

As for graphics and music, not much to say you didn't already know. The game is absolutely gorgeous, as can be seen from screenshots. Everything looks great and the level of detail is kept right up until the very last level.

And the music is Touhou remixes. I have listened to a remix of U.N. Owen Was Her?, remade entirely with Medic and Scout noises from TF2, and I will still swear on my life I've never heard a bad Touhou song or remix. It's an entire album of absolute bangers.

Just play the goddamn game. It's cheap, not very long, and will leave you wanting more. Sakuya is best Touhou.

120970054.review:
Touhou Luna Nights is a short, but really awesome Metroidvania that leans heavily into the Castlevania vibe and references. If you remember the heyday of Castlevania on the Gameboy Advance and Nintendo DS, this fits right in - it's got a lot of the usual Castlevania stages, but like each of those games it has a unique hook. In this case, the hook is time control, both slowing it down and stopping it. It makes extensive use of this mechanic both for combat and some really interesting time puzzles.

One thing to note is that the big difference between Touhou Luna Nights and Castlevania is the Touhou tone to the game. Instead of an apocalyptic battle of good and evil, the story of Touhou Luna NIghts is really about a bunch of super powered friends having friendly challenges and rivalries in a Castlevania castle. It's surprisingly slice of life for a game where you're stopping time and throwing daggers at big monsters. Personally, I loved it.

120860830.review:
You know what game got over 5 million in funding and was backed by 64 thousand people? Not this game- this game was developed by a small team and with a likely much more limited budget. It is far more deserving of the Symphony of the Night spiritual successor title than Bloodstained. There I said it.

This game is absolutely incredible and I found it completely by accident by scrolling through a list of overwhelmingly positive titles and I saw a Touhou game (Which confused me). I have played some Embodiment of Scarlet Devil and I listen to the music occasionally, but that is about the extent of knowledge on the Touhou franchise- but my word if this game doesn't entice me to go play more of the franchise.

This game is a proper metroidvania. It kicks your ass, you figure it out, and you apply those skills to fights later, and all of a sudden you're a pro at playing this game and now you want to speedrun it.

This game follows the formula:

- It teaches you by slowly introducing mechanics to you one at a time.
- You apply those skills en masse when they eventually combine them.
- In failure it teaches you even more about what to do the next time you do a fight or encounter.
- It does not waste your time since saves are at the boss gates.
- It's got excellent synthy music to keep you motivated and interested. (And if you like Touhou music, prepare your body, some good arrangements in here).
- Tight controls and mechanics.
- Actions and fights are repeatable.
- Once you have gained mastery you feel overpowered, nothing feels better in a game than when that happens.
- It’s not painstakingly long, 5-10 hours on your first run depending on your skill level, and it appears (from speedrun dot com) < 1 hour if you git gud on repeat runs.

I also like the fact that it's not just Touhou themed in characters, settings, and music- but they brought in the mechanics- like they sprinkled some bullet hell in, learning placement / when to move vs staying put, and grazing for HP/MP recovery. It is an outstanding and well thought out game that stays true to the core games mechanics and the general vibe summer.

To be clear I'm not without minor complaints:

Story Is Pretty Meh / Non Existent
This is sorta on brand for Touhou and I don't hate it- at least it's not lying to me about the importance of it with some shitty excuse plot. Let's be real, no one actually cares about why you're killing Mother Brain in Super Metroid. You just want to play the game, fight shit, kill the animals, and fuck off. Truthfully it is sort of a breath of fresh air when you just got done playing a 120 hour plot driven RPG game. So for me not really a complaint. However, it might be for you, but I also think you’re looking in the wrong category. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Time Stop / Knife Jump
You can get stuck with time stopping because you jump with your knives or use your knives. Actually the whole knife jump + time stop thing could use a rework it's a bit jank.

Extra Area / Bosses
I think the extra area was too easy and too short, with that said I did enjoy the final fight with Reimu. I just wish the extra section was just a bit harder.

Goddamn though, if this game isn't near perfect in my eyes. This is the sort of games we need- not grossly overfunded (and late) kickstarters or games with movie level budgets and development / release cycles that teeter on approaching the inevitable heat death of the universe. We need more of this.

Thank you for making this game and know your work is appreciated by some of us. I would love a sequel that is far larger than this game with even harder content. However, it is unlikely at this point based on some of the things I’ve read.

For everyone else, buy this game, play it, you're gonna love it. If you like metroidvanias you have no excuse not to play this game. It’s relatively cheap, it’s fairly short so it’s not going to waste your time. It's a better use of your money than a lot of other games (or worse, DLC) on steam.

Final Note: If you love this game, write a review, tell your friends to play this game because that is the only way we might get to see more excellent content like this.

119415395.review:
9/10, very short game but worth every penny

I like this game enough that I want to actually write a full review for it and that's pretty rare.

Graphics: 10/10
The spritework in this game is great, Sakuya is fluidly animated and the entire thing is oozing with style.
I like Nitori's robot.

Sound: 10/10
The soundtrack in the game is great, but when Sakuya's theme hits it takes the game to a whole other level.
Also be prepared to hear "SNAIL TIME" a lot during boss fights.

Story: ?/10
I don't know much about Touhou so I can't say whether the story in this particular game is good or not. As a standalone game, there wasn't much of a story to begin with and some of the dialog was oddly translated, but you don't really play this game for the story.
I think it can be mostly summed up as "Cute Girls Doing Cute Things" but with anime superpowers involved.

Gameplay: 9/10
Though this game might look and feel like a Metroidvania, it is every bit of a Bullet Hell Shmup at heart.

You'll often end up in situations where you're surrounded by screen-filling attacks and the only way out is to slow down time to be able to dodge out of the way, which this game refers to as a "Graze".
The Graze system isn't for everyone and can take some getting used to, but it's an interesting mechanic once you've got it down.

The controls are tight and responsive, and *most* of the time mistakes feel like they're actually your fault as opposed to bad game design.
Sakuya has a cool moveset, though some of the level design decisions made regarding how late in the game you unlock certain abilities seem a bit odd.

My main complaint with the game is probably that Sakuya is *incredibly* squishy and will very easily die in just a few hits. There is technically a story reason for why she's as weak as she is while the other characters/bosses have health in the 10k HP range, but spending 5-10 minutes whittling down a boss's HP bar when you can only take maybe 5 hits from full health without Grazing seems just a liiiiiiiiitle unbalanced.

Not only that, Sakuya takes a ridiculous amount of knockback from *every* hit so you're often sent flying somewhere that you don't want to be. That, combined with the period of invincibility that you get after being hit being ridiculously short, leads to many situations where you can effectively get juggled by enemies and die without being able to do a lot about it.
The screen just before the secret boss is filled with so many screen-filling enemies that juggle you back and forth that I pretty much spent a whole game session just getting past that one room alone. Yeah, that was a post-game room and was literally the last room in the game, but it seemed a little excessive.

<edit- Spoilers?>
After playing around with a save editor, it Is possible to turn Sakuya into a walking tank like the other characters in the game but getting her to that point requires a ridiculous amount of grinding that most players won't do. I 100%ed the game at level 25 and that was playing at a casual pace and I don't consider myself to be particularly good at the game. S-ranking Boss Rush mode seems to want Sakuya at at *least* level 40 with tons of money put into upgrades if the Achievement Guide is any indication and I doubt anyone but the most hardcore of players would be willing to do the amount of grinding necessary to make up 15+ levels of grinding for money on such a short game.
In this regard, my main complaint as far as gameplay balance seems to come from the fact that you need to gather a ridiculous amount of gems to have any real noticeable effect on Sakuya's stats and there just isn't enough content in the game to collect the number of gems needed in a normal playthrough without grinding.
There is no New Game+ option to allow you to continue collecting money and experience so achievements like the one for beating the game without dying seem like more of a slog than a challenge worth attempting.
<end edit>

My only complaint with the controls is that it's sometimes too easy to attack in the wrong direction. Sakuya has the ability to move in the opposite direction from where she's facing while in a certain attack animation, and this can lead to you attacking in the wrong direction if an enemy jumps behind you and you aren't super careful.

In short, this game is absolutely worth your time (pun intended), especially if you're a fan of the Metroidvania genre.
