117326661.review:
This game. Is very short. Speedrunning it, you can complete it in less than an hour, even a hundred percenting it. Casually on your first playthrough with no prior knowledge of the game, you will most likely take a more standard five hours, but most of this is spent on the obligatory backtracking Metroidvanias are known for. Counting full completion, realistically closer to eight hours. Most backtracking is good, some is bad, but I will get to that later. Another thing too is that this game is nearly twenty bucks, but for the more gifted platformer, this game will hardly give them much bang for their buck. For the more ungifted platformer, however, you may possibly see a more realistic ten hours before full completion, especially if boss fights are not your cup of tea. You will certainly get a lot from this game in that regard.

It also lacks a lot of post-game content past a Boss Rush mode. Not even a couple New Game+ styles such as maybe starting a new game with all your abilities, but have to find collectables again. Or even cooler, enemy difficulty is ramped up a bit. Maybe even both. And the aforesaid "some is bad" moments in backtracking attributes to its sadder attempt at giving itself replay value. I do not mean the Jewel collectathon, which I actually liked. But rather, secret doors rebuilding every time you move to another area. I find that to be petty. They should stay broken. It is just an attempt to give them an excuse to have the player run around longer, which was already fine with the Jewel collecting or even going back for abilities like I did on my first playthrough since I missed over half of them initially. Lastly, for what I will say in this paragraph for now anyway, it feels really sad to not have this kind of game feature co-op. Maybe I got spoiled because of The Amazing Mirror, but Metroidvanias with co-op are so fun. I want more of them to be co-op and this game is not under the guise of your typical corporate mollycoddling where Nintendo will continue their traditions with Metroid to "keep it safe" as a single player experience, likewise with how the closest Konami ever did it with Castlevania was Portrait of Ruin having co-op for Boss Rush mode only. Touhou Luna Nights had plenty of room to have co-op since it was only catering to a smaller audience and it would not have been risky. I would have even settled for it only being usable with Parsec, though having separate screens would be much preferred. I technically have one more thing to scratch on, but I will save it for the end since the buildup to it is more important.

Now then, the moment you have been waiting for. But wait, I am sure you are confused now. "Why did they give it a thumbs up with this many negatives?" Well, my friend, that is because [b]EVERYTHING ELSE ABOUT THE GAME IS GREAT.[/b] I love the atmosphere, the engine is very tight, the music is incredible and I have a very specific bias of this being the first Touhou game I ever experienced, so nearly all of this is fresh to me completely. Touhou Luna Nights may have very well spoiled me in Metroidvanias because I just loved messing around with it. I beat it on Steam and immediately wanted to support the game a second time and beat it on Switch as well. I could not be pulled away from it for so long. I even watched my friend beat the game who was a seasoned Touhou fan and seeing them love the game so much warmed my heart as it made me realize how much it caters to their fan base. The writing was interesting to watch from start to finish. It hardly felt tedious at all past the aforesaid obligatory backtracking, but you can cheese it easily on the second playthrough onward.

This game single-handedly convinced me to enter the Touhou lore altogether and I had only vaguely known the franchise for roughly four years, but not too much past seeing some of its characters in VRChat as my first true exposure to them and knowing of the tracks Night of Knights and Bad Apple. Every time I saw anything MMD related to them, it was still just those two tracks. But every other track in this game was completely brand new to me. And I love their renditions of them. In fact, I love nearly every track in the game and I am very picky on my musical tastes, so that means a lot coming from me. I have not played a video game in years where the atmosphere of a boss fight was so perfect I felt like I was actually there for a second. In particular, fighting Remilia, her telling you of her fake world, fighting you, being proud of what you have achieved and the music almost perfectly building on all the right moments of the fight. Honestly had me in some tears and that was a weird emotion to feel well playing an action video game. But it was just so powerful. I loved every second of it.

And speaking of what I said earlier, this is where the biggest crash of my positives begin. I felt this exact same way about another fight, Cirno. To my knowledge, she was the first Touhou character I ever laid eyes upon, so she holds the most nostalgic attachment to me in that regard. Not that it necessarily makes her my favorite, but her fight was fairly unique in its setup (no pun intended). From my understanding of her lore, she is a character picked on a lot and is overall incompetent, even showing that a bit in the cutscenes. But, she puts on enough of a show to convince Sakuya to respect her effort and her track has a really nice "triumphant" feel to it as well, almost like Cirno wants to prove she can at least leave a dent in Sakuya and the aftermath cutscene is her reward. Only for it to comically fall apart after Sakuya respects her being near the end of her journey and Cirno quite literally brings up if that was the first stage. Hence, why she says Remilia sent her. But on the bright side, Cirno is still harder than Meiling, so I would respectfully put her as a second stage boss myself.

"Where is the crash?" Here it is. Cirno is somehow completely omitted from the Boss Rush mode entirely. Based on my research of this, I just have no clue why, but she is not there. My previous criticisms I will not label as big because it is me expecting the game to give me more than what it did, such as the aforesaid co-op I wish it had. But, a [b]big[/b] criticism I will give this game is being the first Boss Rush I ever played to not have every single boss included. It just feels like a massive oversight and it is amazing it has not been addressed. There are not even mods of the game to properly return Cirno to it either, so what you see is what you get. For those who want to fight her multiple times, I suggest a second save file that specifically ends before the Cirno fight. Her pattern is fun, the music is great and the only real downside is you can not do it with all of your abilities like you can in Boss Rush. Specifically, only losing Dash Spike and Bound Knife, which are not really necessary to beat her if you just spam Thousand Daggers like everyone else does, but can at least add some flavor if you fight her without using that broken weapon. Ice Magatama is just to get around fire barriers and serves no significant purpose by being in your kit in Boss Rush. Maybe people would think she is too easy, but Meiling is dirt easy in Boss Rush. And re-balancing the rank system for the achievements would not be hard at all.

[i]To summarize:[/i]
+ Great sprite work.
+ Incredible soundtrack.
+ Very solid game engine.
+ Charming writing.
+ Fun replay value in regard to Boss Rush mode.
- Not having any kind of New Game+ features, such as Hard Mode, play with all your abilities, etc.
- A smaller nitpick, but not having co-op.
- [b]Cirno being absent from Boss Rush.[/b]
- Very short if you are a seasoned platformer.

You owe it to yourself to try this game if you love platformers and especially Metroidvanias. I have played many in the genre and this game is hands down my favorite. If twenty feels a bit much for it, wait until it is ten on sale. You won't regret.

117296298.review:
This game is something.

So I'm gonna start with the controls.
If you've ever played Cave Story, then you've already got a nice amount of experience in the controls. They work fantastically, and if you don't like the controls, you can change them with ease.

Next is the difficulty, and it's a really annoying topic for me.
The bosses in this game are amazing, they're so good I wouldn't even call them boss battles, they're full on showdowns. I LOVE the showdowns, they're so well crafted and the music that plays in them are so good, the music is literally MIDI music and it still sounds beautiful. That being said, the difficulty in everything OTHER than these showdowns, is fucking stupid. So. Fucking. Stupid.
You get 100 health at the start, and you can upgrade it easily, HOWEVER  enemies deal borderline retarded damage. I mean like, SPECIAL ED LEVEL RETARD DAMAGE. Enemies at the start can and will take you from 100 to 80 in one hit, and it only gets worse from there. Playing the game for the extremely well thought out showdowns is exactly what it was meant for, but the "downtime" it gives you is like fighting that same boss several times at once.

If you can get past that, please buy this game. It is SO worth the money.

117244951.review:
This is basically the best Metroidvania in this price range. The game is short, but it's also a third of the price of most full blown Metroidvanias. The presentation is quite good, but the English localisation is not entirely up to par. The writing very occasionally feels off. However, the strength of Luna Knights isn't in the writing anyway, it's the gameplay. The entire game is based around time manipulation (you are play as Sakuya, after all), and that is so fun. And the game is also balanced around this, so it makes you feel overpowered even though you actually aren't that overpowered. It's a great feeling. This was a good 6-7 hour ride (if you want to 100% the game, minus Boss Rush S rank).

Also, you are playing as Sakuya Izayoi, and without a nerfed time stopper. This alone should be an auto-buy. We need more games that allow the main character to stop time at will from the get go.

116269327.review:
Short but very clever. The time stop mechanics are incredibly well integrated, being absolutely necessary for survival. Graze an enemy while time is normal to get back HP, graze while they're frozen to gain MP... attacks eat MP, or during time stop it consumes clock time. Double jump throws a couple knives at the ground, and helps you restore MP faster cuz you can recover knives stuck in walls/floors. The "get even higher" special is jumping on your time-stopped knives. Just so damn clever, see. 

Areas are short enough that your walks between warp zones aren't too bad when going back to find more stuff.

Only real complaints I have are:

- After you get the "get higher" power your knives become a bit of a liability... they act like walls, so throw them at the wrong time, or double jump while stopped, and you have yourself a tricky situation where the knives are locking you into position. But you figure it out, and it's okay. 

- No color coding of doors you need to get through, so once you get a key you're doing the old stare down at the map trying to remember where you saw it. Same thing when you get the screw knives. Would be helpful to have at least a marker system.

Anyway, quite good. I'm not sure if it's 18 dollars good, but 10 or less and it would be perfect. Really too short for much more than that.

115435446.review:
Me hubiera gustado terminarlo y es gracioso porque he completado juegos muchos más difíciles que este pero me es imposible disfrutarlo.

Algo que tira para atrás para muchos es que este juego tenga la etiqueta [i]infierno de balas[/i] (bullet hell), un genero muy de nicho que consiste en esquivar todo lo que te suelten sin descanso pero no es un problema en este juego por una simple mecánica que nos hará parar el tiempo, haciendo que el bullet hell no sea un infierno de balas como su nombre indica y sea cosa de pensar en cada momento cuando activarlo para parar el ataque que se deja entrever que es imposible de otra manera. También se usa en todo momento fuera de los jefes para puzzles sencillos o incluso para facilitar el combate de ciertos enemigos. 
Pero hay algo en este juego que tira por la borda todo y es su sistema de "estamina", en este juego lo llaman [i]MP[/i] y lo que hace es que cuando gastas munición esa barra ira disminuyendo hasta que quede a 0 y su única forma de recuperla es parando el tiempo en circunstancias adecuadas, recogiendo la munición que quedo clavada en alguna pared o gastar las gemas que conseguiste para comprar "pociones" que recargue tu MP. Con los jefes pasa una cosa y es que no paran de lanzarte ataques y que muchos de estos aun usando la mecánica de parar el tiempo te podrán dar porque son muy inconsistentes y realmente no seria un problema si no fuera porque el sistema de MP te alarga exageradamente el combate teniendo que pasar por muchos ataques sin que tu le estés haciendo nada de daño.

[h1]Más puntos negativos:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]La mecánica MP esta mal diseñada alargando los jefes y haciendo que estés expuesto a muchos fallos sin poder hacer nada mas que esquivar y recargar munición a paso de tortuga.
    [*]El mapa es una completa basura no puedes marcar nada ni tampoco es intuitivo es un completo caos. El peor mapa que he visto en un metroidvania.
    [*]El teletransporte mas cercano a la tienda esta demasiado lejos que antes te da para varios intentos en un jefe que ir al teletransporte más cercano para quedar al quinto c*** de la tienda. Absurdo.
    [*]Cuando inicias el juego te pone ciertos ajustes a modificar como la resolución pero cuando intentas modificarlos automática se quita y entras en el menú para empezar a jugar o salir. Dice que presiones el botón de mover pero eso igual activara la opción de jugar, no tiene sentido la verdad.
    [*]Como metroidvania es muy decepcionante, es muy lineal y las habilidades solo sirven para avanzar. Es un juego de plataformas de acción.
[/list]

Si te gusta o no te importa mucho que tenga combates innecesariamente largos contra los jefes, ver como no puedes hacer nada mientras te fulminan con ataques, eres fan de Touhou y por supuesto si no buscas un metroidvania sino un juego de acción lineal, no voy a ser yo quien te impida comprarlo porque no todo es malo, es mas sin no fuera por eso el MP lo estaría recomendando sin duda algunas.

113482362.review:
Uno de los mejores juegos que he jugado.
Quisiera extenderme más en mi reseña pero solo te diré que es hermoso. Un estilo de juego muy dinámico y viciante, es como estar danzando en cada pelea de jefes, tiene su reto. 
Un hermoso metroidvania y uno de los mejores que si te encanta TOUHOU, un poco la dificultad como reto y la acción muy dinámica te va a encantar, su sistema de recuperación de Vida y Energía es una gozada porque trabaja con el movimiento de riesgo recompensa de "rozar" a los enemigos, agregándole un sentimiento de adrenalina ligera y satisfacción colosal sobre todo en las batallas contra los jefes, que dios, las primeras veces que te las pasas son memorables y muy bonitas. De lo mejor que he podido jugar en el estilo sin duda.
Que decir de lo visual es hermoso el trabajo de pixel art, pero rayando en el arte, así de lindo es a primera vista.
La música es una gozada y más si eres un fan de la música del mundo de Touhou, aquí particularmente durante el gameplay y los jefes queda de manera sublime para acompañar y amenizar tu aventura.
Para mi gusto su duración me ha dejado satisfecho y ha sido excelente casi lo termino al 100% solo dejándolo justo en 99% de una, y lo jugué varias veces incluso en varias plataformas y controles, teclado y gamepad y en ambos me fascinó, me encantó tanto que lo compré para consola y computadora. y la primera vez que lo toqué no pude dejar de jugarlo en todo el día hasta que mi cuerpo no pudo más.
No he hablado de otro aspecto genial de este titulo y es que ademas puedes pausar el tiempo e interactuar con está mecánica de administrar el control de las situaciones y librarte de ataque o generarlos de manera muy épica con todo el arsenal de armas que vas juntando a tu disposición durante tu avance por los mapas con sus pequeños puzzles de plataformas y zonas ocultas. Mejorando cada vez más tu poder y el tiempo que puedes pausar. Puzzles que son esenciales usar estas mecánicas y explotarlas así como también ralentizar el tiempo, entre más entiendes el juego y más avanzas más lo disfrutas, y ni hablar de lo agradable que es el sistema de "energía/magia/maná" que también puedes interactuar de maneras distintas intercalando entre si el tiempo esta detenido o no, recuperando de los enemigos ya sea vida o energía según el caso, algo que solo lo vuelve mejor aún.
No podría acabar de resaltar cada una de las interacciones con las distintas armas, pero en general son muy placenteras de usar e inclusive tus ataques básicos principales, así como hay unas habilidades también muy chetas y tal.
Una gozada de juego que está en mi top tier porque soy muy fan de todo esto, las monitas chinas, pixel art, touhou con su buena música y lore, y el metroidvania. Esto sumándole una acción tremendamente satisfactoria y muy dinámica entre también sus pausas y jugar con ese equilibrio del tiempo.
La verdad la historia principal está muy bien y su duración jefes epicardos, escenarios muy buenos. Muy entretenido y divertido.
Toda una experiencia la verdad destacar algunos Jefes que son bellisimos y que incluso casi a mitad de juego y poco más adelante bien podría acabar quizás y ya sería feliz pero está lleno de muchos, una pequeña historia muy genial y unos plot twist la verdad muy épicos y disfrutables. 

XD Me pasé el juego sin usar los consumibles de la tienda XD no sé ni en que momento pero fue genial.

podría hablar todo el día y más sobre el juego, pero simplemente lo amé así bien fanboy yo fácil le pondría un 10/10 (｡♥‿♥｡) y así siendo objetivos te diría que es un muy buen juego que deberías probar. c:

113177762.review:
Takoyaki
The ultimate Japanese street snack, now in your own home. Have a takoyaki party this weekend!

Here’s what you need:
Eggs. Eggs make up the majority of the batter and help it get crisp.
Flour. Flour binds everything together into a very loose batter.
Dashi powder. Dashi powder is what gives the batter it’s flavor – it’s a simple shortcut way of incorporating dashi (Japanese soup stock) into the base. You can buy dashi powder in the Asian grocery store or online. It adds a bunch of flavor and umami.
Soy sauce. This is just to add some extra flavor.
Octopus/tako. The reason why we’re here! You can buy already cooked tako at the Asian grocery store in the seafood section. Cut the tako up into cubes.
Green onions. These add a bit of freshness to the takoyaki.
Tenkasu. Tenkasu is tempura bits! They add texture and aroma. If you don’t have any (they sell them in bags at the Asian grocery store) then you can sub in rice krispies.
Takoyaki sauce. A thick brown sweet and savory sauce.
Kewpie mayo. This is essential and gives your octopus balls that iconic look.
Bonito flakes. These flakes are what make your takoyaki look like it’s dancing! They are delicate, paper thin shaved dried fish that wave around from the hot steam. They are super savory.
Seaweed. A little green sprinkle of powdered seaweed.

How to make takoyaki
Mix. Mix the batter up with a whisk making sure there are no floury bits.
Prep. Prep all of the fillings. Cut up the octopus, slice the green onions and make sure you have everything at the ready: a little dish of oil, all your ingredients, some skewers to flip the balls, and a plate to serve on. Heat up the pan.
Pour and fill. Generously oil the pan with a brush or a paper towel dipped in oil. Give the batter a whisk then pour into the individual compartments all the way up to the top. It’s okay if they overflow a bit. Add in the fillings and let cook until the edges start to look more solid and opaque.
Flip. Use your skewers to turn the takoyaki 90 degrees. If they don’t easily move, they need more time to crisp up. Once they’re at a 90° angle, pour in a bit more batter to ensure a super round ball. Let cook, stuffing in any excess batter that’s outside the ball, then turn again. You should have a round ball. Cook until the balls are crispy and brown, moving the balls around from mold to mold to evenly cook (this is because most pans will have uneven heating). As the balls crisp up, it will be easier to flip them.
Sauce. When the balls are golden and crisp, pop them on a plate and brush with takoyaki sauce and squeeze on some mayo.
Top. Finish with a sprinkle of bonito and aonori. Enjoy!

I played this game, took a break from it, and came back to it a year later after learning more about Touhou and its world. When I loaded my save, I was placed 4 rooms before the final boss with no knowledge besides a bunch of buttons that I had to relearn. I did so swiftly, finishing the game with only a few deaths and retries before accomplishing what I thought I couldn't only a year ago. This is why I think Touhou Luna Nights one of the easiest games to get into, and maybe the easiest to master, while still containing a lot of depth in the movement, traversal, and combat (if you don't spam Thousand Daggers). After only a day, I've defeated the final boss, completed the extra stage, and achieved 100% completion. I then went on to complete another run entirely with almost 100% completion minus the large gem stones, in only 2 hours of gameplay.
This game is phenomenal. You should get it, even if you don't know what Touhou is. This was my first game in the series, and it introduced me to so many characters I ended up loving, and returning to this game again knowing them and their origins made it even more enjoyable than just the gameplay my second time around.
Only problem is that I did not receive my achievement for not using the Retry button on my last run. If the criteria have changed for the No Continues for You achievement, I would have liked to know sooner.

I'm surprised this game was worth my 20 dollars. I was actually extremely reluctant to pay full price, but I had great expectations for it and they sure were satisfied. 

Absolutely BEAUTIFUL spritework, smooth-as-butter animations, great linear pacing, eargasm-worthy soundtrack and gameplay that leaves you wanting much, MUCH more.

110700535.review:
Great both for those experienced with Touhou and those new to it. The characters (with the exception of Akyuu) are all well known and relatively popular. Since the game's world is detached from that of the main Touhou series, the story is self contained and doesn't end up contradicting anything in the main series. I had seen the final boss before playing, but I did not expect the plot twist at the end.

Of course, that's all about the story, but the gameplay is also great. When I first saw the game, I didn't expect it to reach the same level of bullet hell that Touhou does, but the later bosses (ESPECIALLY REIMU) proved me wrong. Graze is a great translation from the main games and serves as a great risk-reward system, offering health, mp, and time, in exchange for a large risk in getting hit. Again, when I first saw the game, I thought that stopping time would completely break the game and make it really easy. However, the inclusion of green and purple bullets prevents that issue, not to mention that graze is less effective when time is stopped, encouraging the player to play risky. If I had one complaint, it would be that the secret rooms can be hard to find. The inclusion of the lost holy sword, which is an endgame item, removes this, as, when it is active, the sword will automatically reveal secret rooms, meaning that an endgame sweep of the map isn't tedious. The music is great as always, and it's varied enough to not get grating while you play.

Overall, if you've been on the fence about trying Touhou, this is a great entry point to see if you're interested in the world and characters. Even if you're already a fan of the games, the game is worth trying to see how all of the mechanics are translated into the metroidvania format.

New player mechanics are steadily introduced, allowing you to backtrack to pass certain obstacles but it never feels as though the game is being padded out.

I know very little about Touhou, but the characters seem interesting at a glance and I might give some more mainline Touhou games a try.

110276351.review:
Gameplay: 
The game gets very creative with the time manipulation and types of weapons you get. Once Sakuya gains the ability to walk and jump on time-frozen knives, the game becomes a whole different beast.
It makes each tool useful for combat, platforming and puzzles in their own way. 
The "Graze" mechanic functions extremely well here. Grazing past enemies and projectiles is the fastest way to recover MP so it incentives the player to stop throwing knives from a safe distance and maneuver between the enemies using the different knife types as platforms or for attacking. Brilliant stuff.

Music: 
The sound tracks fit all the stages and they hype you up for the whole journey. 

Story: 
Its not very deep but it serves its purpose: giving some time to breath from the tense combat, giving a goal and a mystery to look forward to.

Presentation:
The animations are great (maybe the walk cycle is a bit wonky). Most of the enemies look great. The stages look sleek. The hud and menus look and function great. 

Final comment:
It's hard to put into words how fun it is to stop time and jump on all the frozen knives you've thrown. You just gotta play it to get how it feels.

108424407.review:
[h1] The Great:[/h1]
- Challenging difficulty. There is a challenge to be found in both the combat and the map puzzles
- Excellent pixel artwork, both for the characters, items, and level aesthetic.
- The time stop mechanic is very fun, and fairly balanced. Sure, you can demolish bosses in boss rush after becoming fully upgraded using it, but throughout your regular first playthrough it feels balanced enough.
- The story is very simple yet fun; it isn't intrusive nor does it take up the majority of the game. And people unfamiliar with Touhou can still enjoy it.
- Boss rush mode is a fun way to raise your level.
- Very nice music, all of them being remixes of classic Touhou tunes.

[h1] The Good: [/h1]
- You can enjoy this game without knowing a single thing about Touhou. Like me. Coming into this game, I only knew about the strongest and smartest fairy Cirno from memes (don't worry, she's in this game) and that Bad Apple video. Nothing else lmao.
- There is a really nice variety of enemies. Some are "reskins" of older enemies, but are done so in a way that makes them a step-up from their older and weaker counterparts and keeps the game interesting.
- There are different kinds of skills that you can find and unlock to make your kills more efficient. A few of them are kinda useless imo, but others are incredibly fun to abuse.
- There are DOOM-style secrets of hidden passageways found in normal-looking walls that creates an incentive to search around the levels for bonus stuff.

[h1] The Bad: [/h1] 
- There are a few bugs that can softlock you and force you to start from a save point. Thankfully, these moments are rare. My word of advice: don't time stop when you're inside water.
- Cirno isn't in the boss rush. Why.

[h1] Notes: [/h1]
- I had no knowledge of this funny Jojo reference lady with the time stop and knives is, but she's kinda cute.
- I also had no idea that this was a fan game. In fact, most Touhou games in the Steam store are fan games. Guess I gotta play to real stuff now.
- I wish Cirno was in the boss rush segment. Please make it happen.

[h1] FINAL VERDICT: 9/10. "1, 2... 9!" [/h1]

108108949.review:
This is my first real review, I would start by saying I hate writing essays and my grammar is terrible, but I feel I gotta make one for this game for more attention. To start off, wanting to get into the Touhou series, I was recommended this game due to already being a big Castlevania SOTN fan and to start soaking in all the info about these characters, names, personality, music etc. So, I played, from beginning to All Clear with 100% of the map covered and oh boy it was a journey. Now to some topics I want to talk about:
-STORY: I found the story to be pretty enjoyable and easy to understand for someone who just started the series with this game. I feel it was satisfying enough to explain why this was happening and why go through this journey. 

-CHARACTERS: I would say that characters in this game was fun to get to know to say the least, but most of them I wish I could’ve got to know more of. I wish that many of them would appear more often throughout the game instead of just appearing for a boss fight then never seen again. However, I really enjoyed Sakuya as a main character and was able to get a lot of info about who she is and her powers. I say she definitely the star of the game and best girl 

-SETTING: I really love the setting of the game mostly because of it giving nostalgic feelings of CastleVania SOTN but still stands to me as its own place and not just a carbon copy of the castle. 

-MUSIC: OMG, this game soundtrack was amazing. While I do know mostly all these songs comes from the original series, I really enjoyed this newer rendition of these songs as my first time hearing them in general. One thing I can tell about the series in general is that their music is top notch and defiantly deserves all its popularity.

-GAMEPLAY: IT’S LITTERALY SOTN….. with some very fun mechanics. I found the gameplay to be absolutely fun due to playing like a mertoidvania game, but it's time mechanic was something so refreshing. I feel they struck gold with time stop due to being a mechanic that was able to make some fun puzzles and be a lifesaver in battle at the same time. The weapons in this game were also fun. Though definitely the Thousand knives were my most used weapon by a long shot, the other weapons like holy sword, shield and chainsaw were also super helpful and save me a lot as well. The graze system in this game was also a lovely addition, I love how dodging in this game felt so rewarding due to graze, especially on later bosses where I was able to gain health back during these. Speaking of which, the bosses in this game are definitely the most fun part, it really puts use of everything you acquire and learn thus far into action which I love. Last thing is that Sakuya handles very well, and all her movement was spot on, no issues there (at least on a ps4 controller).

-DIFFCULTY: I’ll say is average compared to other games in the genre, not too easy but not too difficult. I say it manageable if it’s your first ever mertoidvania game, but I will say the spike from regular enemies to bosses are a bit high but after a couple of tries, you will start getting the hang of how-to doge each attack. Also, there isn’t too much health/save points/teleports locations but would say it's enough, maybe a bit more teleports especially could’ve help 

-NEGATIVES: While I am basically praising the game to death, there are some things that I did dislike about the game. My main issue with the game to me at least is the length of the game itself. I feel this game was a bit too short for me, I really wish there was at least 2 or more areas and bosses to explore/fight. While I do have 8hrs in gametime, some was spent just casually walking around/grinding, so really could’ve beaten the game in around 6 and a half. I really wanted this game to be longer, but it wasn’t the end of the world due to me still feeling satisfied at the end. Another negative is some of the items and abilities you get throughout the game being very under used or obsolete. Why the stun knife is the first weapon you do get, I definitely did not used it since it didn’t really help to much and everything else out class it. The bounce knife, the LAST weapon you’ll get, also had this issue of already being obsolete compared to others. With abilities, I found the screw knife to be under used, I think you only use it 4 times, and also dislike you get the dash ability so LATE in the game. Last is I wish they would’ve focused very early on about how gems truly work. I didn’t really need the shop though since I never bought anything but would still be nice if others can use it without costing important resources to your stats.

CONCLUSION: Even with the negatives I mentioned above, I still love this game to death. It’s Gameplay and Music is what I would consider making this game a must play even if you never played a mertoidvania or touhou game. While this game isn’t a bullet hell unlike the main entries, I feel this game should defiantly be praise as a main entry and an entry for others to get into the series. It defiantly borrows a lot of what made SOTN great, but I still feel Team LadyBug created something super unique and turn it out amazing. With that, I’ll say I give this game a 9/10 and do hope will get to see a sequel with Sakuya still the MC, and by the same staff.

107500907.review:
Imagine "Castlevania: Symphony of The Night" but with Touhou characters instead. That's pretty much what this game is all about, a "metroidvania". Despite the homages this game is making (the games being very difficult), this is not a hard game. But it can be a fun challenge for the casual gamer. And even if you don't know the story behind the Touhou franchise or the characters, the gameplay is what makes this game a very good one to play.

The ability of stopping time and using the items that you collect through the game without spending or wasting any points while time is stopped, it's a very fun mechanic. Some enemies can be tough to beat as the game progresses, and some levels will drive you mad at times. 

Something curious about this game is the fact that it has a shop, but you don't really need to spend any money on said shop. If you are good at the game, you can find all the skills and items that you need to beat the game through the map, hidden in secret rooms, without spending any gems. But gotta say, the last bosses will require you to get many of items and upgrades in the game. 

In my opinion, a criticism I can make to this game is that when facing the bosses, evading and dodging some of their powers can heal you and refill your skill points and time points pretty quickly. This makes the boss fights very easy once you understand how they work, and makes the items in the shop useless. It is also a very short game that you can probably beat like in 2 or 3 days. But despite these minor flaws, the game is very fun. 

I say get it on a sale. It is entertaining, the pixel art and animations are fantastic, the music is great, the "time stop" mechanics are addictive and unique, and if you are a Touhou or a Castlevania fan, you are definitely gonna enjoy it. An entertaining short game, fun bosses with a bit of challenge at later stages and a very nice soundtrack. Very recommendable.

106934549.review:
[b][i]English translation.[/i][/b]

It’s a very unusual and pretty complex igawania. It’s interesting but also this set of mechanics makes it more fiddly and hard than precise and satisfying. Near-hits replenish HP, MP and the timer, which can be exchanged for a time-freeze and any movement or attacks during it. While the time is frozen the radius of near-hits becomes pretty big, but now they replenish only MP in limited amounts per threat. And yes, you can camp near some stationary enemies to replenish your HP by two points per attack. You will. Some save-points are pretty far apart and the fourth level is filled with spikes and rotating blades of all configurations.
So this is less of an action game, and more of resource juggling and precise planning of a route. During the early game, it is necessary to stop time near every petty enemy to replenish MP — since the second level, the game has flying enemies which are evading the basic attack and non-guided magic. And the basic attack drains MP too anyway. The time-stopping plays an animation instead of being instantaneous. It should be at least faster. There are several environmental hazards or boss attacks that can be avoided only through time manipulation. But it’s impossible to tell which parts of the art-assets are hit-boxes. And the result is unpredictable — sometimes those let the character pass other times they deal damage. And the worst part is the abundance of particles in the animations and the similarity of the colours between the character’s attacks and enemy’s. During a fight, the challenge is to actually see where is the danger in this blinking mess covering the whole screen. The picture is pretty often entirely unreadable. It’s not as much of a precision game as a war of attrition. The combat is more complex and drawn out, than plain hard. Even with the high damage from enemies, it’s always about accumulating mistakes than missing one fatal blow.
The game has JRPG levelling, but it’s more pointless than ever. It’s very hard to notice any improvements from a new level. The EXP requirements curve is very temperate but even the late-game enemies rarely bring ten points or more. The most effective way to grind is to find a gathering of 2xp “boars” near a replenishing station on the first level and just pop in and out of the room while spamming homing magic.
Instead of pure cash enemies drop gems, and those can even improve the character’s stats. But the % are so low that there is no actual benefit to it. I never saw the declared HP regen in action even after collecting several hundreds of emeralds. Not even a single HP. It’s better to just sell the gems to the shopkeep and buy several upgrades for the gauges and spend the remaining on the expensive HP\\MP potions. Some magics make most boss fights trivial, but if the player fails to notice those or can’t find the unlocking cards, end-game boss fights will require the usage of potions. But unlike Dracula X 2 medkits are used in real-time without any menus. With the same interface as Rodoss and SMT games but without a breather to orient oneself in the stupid inventory.

The saving and replenishing stations are automatic and are triggered just by walking through them. Now that’s a real quality of life improvement over Akumajo Dracula games. And the replenishers even have a mini-game. The character drinks a canned drink and drops the can, so the player can time it to be dropped into nearby rubbish bins for 10 coins and an achievement. But i still see no reason why save stations, replenishers, teleports and shops aren’t combined into one room. Instead, there is only one shop but it sells consumables to summon it anywhere, even into a boss fight. Now that’s weird, why would anyone do that instead of calling the delivery into a clearly telegraphed save room right before the fight? Which only proves that all four stations should be combined into one, instead of wasting the player’s time on commute. The checkpoints replenish all the gauges on death anyway. It’s as if the game proposes to the player to off themself when they reach a safe point, just to not run around with 10% HP.

[i][b]И тут котёнок is lucid dreaming.[/b][/i]

So, this is my first Touhou game and i severely disliked the series because i don’t understand the lore. I even opened a wiki and it doesn’t have the series’ storyline. And yep, this game didn’t help at all. It’s easy to get the events from the in-game dialogues, but that didn’t tell me anything about the world. And this all is diegetically a game anyway and isn’t related to the main series, these non-events aren’t even canon. The whole writing is childish, but not in the bad sense, it’s childish in the diegetic tone of the english translation.

The stupid tired pixelart is pretty cool-looking and the style of the animation is unusual and attention-grabbing. The protagonist is noodly and has a silly gait. The heal and save station aren’t separate rooms, unrelated to the environment, but a part of it. Even if a foreign one (diegetically). Though, the lower border of the screen has some pointless smoke of mismatching resolution.

Despite being their first full release it is a small and simple game, with limited wares in the store, like a variation on their Tensei-satellite-product. And only after playing something lesser you can appreciate something better. This game is a bit above average, but it is clearly grindier and inferior to the much tighter Shin・megami tensei SYNCHRONICITY PROLOGUE and way smaller and simpler than the Rodosu-to senki —Didoritto・in・wonder labyrinth—.

106869398.review:
TLDR; Very cool game with a lot of poor design choices. 

For $10 on sale this game is definitely well worth it. The graze mechanic and time stop/slow mechanic allows for some very interesting combat/platforming scenarios and overall satisfying gameplay. The bosses are easily the best part, and each feature a moveset that will force the player to engage with the aforementioned mechanics in order to dodge attacks, deal damage, and maintain proper levels of HP and attack points. 

The aesthetic design is nice as well; the characters are waifus, the enemies are cute, the backgrounds and foregrounds have a nice pixelated/modern feel and everything feels very readable. The dialogue is nothing more or less than you'd expect from a Touhou game.

That all being said, this is an incredibly short game. It uses a lot of cheap difficulty tactics, such as save point spacing and boss rushing, making the late game more frustrating and tedious than engaging. Also the player cannot damage enemies or projectiles while they are off screen, which is annoying considering everything offscreen is still "active". 

The secrets in this game are hidden behind walls you have to throw your knives at, and are usually nothing more than a pocket of jewels, increases to your HP/MP, or new special attacks. While secret walls are a staple of games like Metroid, Castlevania, and Hollow Knight etc., there is virtually zero indication for them in this game, nothing which draws the players attention in a meaningful way, and I discovered about half of them just by engaging in combat with the enemies and happening to hit the wall by missing a knife throw. 

All in all, if you're looking for a fun, challenging, cheap metroidvania kinda game with an interesting and satisfying combat loop, Luna Nights is worth a playthrough.

105398654.review:
An amazing metroidvania, but a bit on the short side.

We control Sakuya Izayoi through an imaginary space filled with strange enemies, roadblocks, upgrades, time gimmicks, bosses, and everything you expect from a good metroidvania.
The world is rendered in a beautiful pixel art, the art direction is way too good, reminescent of classics such as SotN.
The music is flawless, its really hard to mess up touhou remixes, and team ladybug surely didn't.

Sakuya controls very well, you throw straight knives with the attack button, and can aim them either upwards, or in diagonals while in the air and use special weapons you find hidden in the map a la Castlevania (but you can carry them all at the same time), she can also slow down time and completely stop it for a while, all these abilities are capped by her SP and TIME resources, even so she is kinda really powerful if you know how to use her powers, which even when heavily weakened due to plot reasons make most enemies a joke.
If you have played Touhou you may know about Graze, in Luna Nights grazing enemies and their projectiles is one of the only ways to heal, a nice risk vs reward, but open to abuse if you go near a screen transition and graze an enemy, move between areas and repeat for a full, but slow heal.

Plot is concise and not too deep, you are here for the gameplay and exploration after all.
The bosses can be challenging when fought at lowish levels, but with a few tries they go down without much trouble

Now, onto the bad things
-Game is really short, first run only took about 5~6 hours counting the extra stage
-After you beat it you lust for more game, but there isn't anything else to do
-Gem farming for minimal stat boosts takes an insane ammount of time
-Only really challenging boss IMO was [spoiler] Reimu 2 [/spoiler], almost everyone else fell on the first or second try, and without using healing items.
-Shield subweapon is kinda useless?
-Screenshots in store spoil the bosses although it's not too hard to guess who you will face if you have played the ZUN games

A great game that could have exploited the time control mechanics much more with a bigger map and more content in general, when the credits rolled a tear rolled thru my eyes, knowing that I wouldn't be able to experience this for the first time again.
Overall score: 7/7 I NEED MORE

105384498.review:
Oh boy, time to out myself as a filthy weeaboo nerd.

Touhou Nights is a game where you play as a time travelling maid who has to clean up an entire mansion filled with monsters. Only the mansion is an illusion and your employer is trying to kill you for fun.

It makes sense in context, I swear.

The game is basically a metroidvania with the design of a good mega man game. It has a neat time gimmick instead of items, which actually makes the game more interesting. Gaining abilities for your time powers is pretty nifty since it doesn't require navigating menus and such to equip them most of the time, instead you just add a new kind of ability to stuff you already do. Like being able to climb on top of knives during stopped time, or being able to slide kick under stuff. It makes the travel pretty seamless, and its never a bore to go from place to place due to the enemies being fairly varied and the time stop mechanic allowing you to brute force through areas you don't like dealing with or enemies you don't like fighting.

The art style might be pixelated, but man do they make every pixel count. Bosses have very unique animations for everything, including Marisa who does a spinning landing onto her broomstick every time she comes in for an attack, and they animated every second of that spin. The attacks are pretty easy to see, although dodging is definitely a challenge for some of them. Makes the boss fights feel fair even if you might lose to them a couple of times.

So should you get this game?

Well if you're a Touhou fan, I'd say absolutely. The game is a gem and its a fun addition to the Touhou franchise.

If you're a newcomer, I'd say a cautious yes. The game is really fun, but some of the plot will go over your head if you aren't at least passingly familiar with who all these characters are. Either way, its still worth a try if you see it on sale or are a fan of well made metroidvanias.

I for one am an absolute simp for Touhou. Got the first games back in my high school days when I didn't have a lot of people to hang out with or money to buy games. The english release was free, so...I picked it up to try it.

And now, here I am, in my 30s writing a review for a game about anime girls beating each other up.

Ah well.

TLDR: Its a good game with good music and well designed abilities and levels. Try it. You won't regret it.

102570469.review:
Ok so
Touhou Luna Nights, DIO from Jojo Heritage for the Future getting his own game.
Touhou Luna Nights is a really great game considering it's a fan creation. Particularly Im not that into the Touhou Project series but seeing characters from a bullet hell game fitting so well into a metroidvania style of gameplay is a thing we must admire.
This game is quite short if you just want to beat the game (about 6 hours) but every bit of the time (haha got the joke) you are playing is enjoyful. Like I said before, the entire gameplay concept of this game is DIO- ok, being serious, youll be stopping time all the time (what) and doing all kinds of tricks, especially after all the upgrades you can get. Because of that, youll be feeling like the coolest person on earth.
One thing that is really impressive is how the mechanic of stopping time is not that broken, like, youll have a hard time against some bosses. It is done by limiting how much time you can stop time (what) and wasting your "time" on certain actions, like attacking and walking. Progressing through the game will allow you to have more time to stop time (what) and have more knives available when time is stopped, which is a really cool and clever way of dealing with possible broken machanics.
Like I said, the game is short on time, the story is not something that complex and well thought (still not a bad one) and can be quite easy if you are familiar with metroidvanias. But still, it's a great way to pass the time and enjoy every second you are playing.
The music is a banger and Im listening to it right now as I write this, so yeah, the music is pretty good, espacially the final boss'.
In general, a  solid 8/10

Calling Luna Night a metroidvania would be kinda wrong, the correct definition would be more a touhouvania, there's no drops and the level ups don't increase your stats that much but the game does have a map with secrets and power ups to collect, the backtracking is almost nothing too.

PRO:
+Visually very good.
+Soundtrack is pretty much a remixed 2HU ost, depends on you but in my opinion is good.
+Fighting is kinda weird at the beginng but gives a lot of sadisfaction when mastered.
+The spirit of 2hu is very well reproduced and using Sakuya is just like i would expect (all those ZA WARUDO and daggers make the game get extra points if you are into that).
+No forced level ups because too weak stat wise to beat that boss, something a lot of metroidvania lost in this days.
+++++++++Cirno.

CONS:
-Game is sadly as much fun as short.
-Soundtrack is not for everyone and someone may get bored about the same "overused songs" and would prefer something new, depend on tastes.
-Fighting is not for all and you may not like it at all if you prefer something more "shoot'em up", later you get a skill that can be abused a lot and with a trick you can pretty much attack forever but by doing so the game may lose some of its shine for someone.
-If you don't like 2hu and its characters you may not enjoy this game.
-No real utility for the level ups (aside probably just for the Boss Rush) is something the Level up lovers may dislike.
-Some sections may be quite frustrating for someone, the "stages" can feel harder than the actual bosses sometimes.


In the end:
Luna Nights is a fun game but very short, not for everyone but surely a good game worth to be played.

101625487.review:
I don't understand the overwhelmingly positive status this game holds. Cannot recommend it for a number of reasons:

1. The runtime for the game is incredibly short for a metroidvania. I finished the base game in less than 5 hours, and this includes some idling time.
2. The level and world design is very dull, with only a few platforming ideas explored and an uninspired level layout (especially for a metroidvania) that has you go to location A to get key to open location B for every single level (and only 5 levels on top of this).
3. Other than for the bosses, the combat is way too easy, as you can essentially cheese every enemy with the time stop mechanic. The only difficulty outside of boss fights comes from artificially difficult platforming sections that are over littered with enemies. This is more painful than challenging, but thankfully only appears in the last level.

The bosses are the only redeeming aspect of this game in my mind, so if you only care about good boss fights and money isn't a factor, go for it. Other than that, the game is very skeletal.

100913753.review:
Don't know the first thing about touhou, but genuinely enjoyed the experience.

Amazing gameplay with interesting mechanics such as time-stop and graze. 

Casuals will enjoy the time-stop gameplay, which can be utilized at all times (with the limit of a time meter) for all bosses and exploration. You can sort of design how you annihilate an area of enemies with time-stop and setting up projectiles. Rest assured, even with time-stop the game is not a boring cruise. The game makes you think before rushing, so that you can't exactly clear every area with the same manner. More hardcore players will explore the graze mechanic, and if used optimally bosses can be eliminated in seconds.

Detailed and beautifully animated sprites for both the characters and enemies. 

For such a short (about 5-7 hours) game, the enemy variety is amazing. You will never see the exact same enemy after going through areas after areas.

Story is not mind-blowing or anything, but it is enjoyable for a metroidvania, even without prior knowledge of touhou lore.

For post game there is boss rush, which contributes to the replayability.

Replayability only exist due to the fun factor. There are no extra ending or anything to achieve (other than the "no continue" achievement). But the fun factor is great enough that you may come back for more.

TLDR; One of a kind metroidvania with unique mechanics, albeit short content-wise. Could use some expansion. Highly recommended if you are looking for a great and unique experience.

100812464.review:
This game's grazing mechanic is insanely addicting. Knowing how to properly react to boss patterns, which attacks are your HP/MP graze salvation, and when to unleash your time-stop mechanic really make this an incredibly unique Metroidvania experience. I actually liken this far more to a Metroid experience; the levels and RPG mechanics are far lighter, and, in fact, the game can indeed be defeated with a relatively very low level.

Save points and warp portals are a bit nerve-wrackingly far apart for what can, however, be a very stingy game. Healing is expensive, attacks deal heavy amounts of damage, and recovering through graze can be incredibly risky. This is something Luna Nights wears proudly.

The warp portals being so sparse however makes backtracking in exploration a bit too much of a chore. But the game has plenty of Metroid-like platforming challenges that truly test that time mechanic beautifully.

In the end, the ultimate victor can simply be a death of a thousand knives, but for someone in the thicket of this mysterious not-so Gensokyo realm; what a treat it was.

99239701.review: This game is an incredible little metroidvania centered around a specific mechanic that feels so much fun to use. The ability to stop & slow time in this game is as important and natural as jumping, both as a way to solve puzzles and to fight enemies. Stopping time to flood the screen with knives and escape enemies feels incredibly fun and unique. There is only a hint of exploration in this game, to find hidden extra powerups, but where it really shines is the absolutely incredible boss battles. This game recreates the wild, gorgeous, and tense feeling of bullet curtains in a platformer, and it works so well. Finally, the music is straight bangers the whole way through, and the art is lively and colorful. It's a shorter game, 10 hours or so, and those 10 hours are dense and fun.

98871958.review:
Touhou Luna Nights es un [b]Metroidvania cargadito de acción basado en Touhou 6[/b] (la sexta entrega principal de la franquicia).

Sakuya, nuestra protagonista (y quinto jefe del Touhou 6 original), despierta en un mundo similar a Gensokyo (lugar en el que la franquicia siempre toma lugar) sin sus poderes. Su deber será explorar este mundo, recuperar sus poderes y llegar hasta el fondo del asunto.

Gráficamente, el [b]pixel art[/b] del que hace gala [b]le queda como anillo al dedo[/b]. [b]Excelentes sprites, efectos y animaciones[/b]. [b]Escenarios muy detallados y diversos[/b] representando muy bien cada una de las partes la mansión escarlata. Su estilo artístico en ocasiones me ha recordado a Cave Story, por lo que personalmente se lleva otro puntito.

El apartado sonoro [b]está conformado por remixes de los mitiquísimos temas de las entregas principales[/b] (principalmente de Touhou 6). Si sois asiduos a la franquicia, reconoceréis todos y cada uno de los temas y no podréis evitar que se os escape una sonrisa cuando los reconozcáis. Personalmente, en este apartado se lleva un 10, ya que tengo mucho cariño a la banda sonora de Touhou 6.

La jugabilidad [b]mezcla acción y exploración a partes iguales[/b] como buen Metroidvania. Es un juego que requiere manos rápidas y es difícil, pero [b]los controles son suaves y muy precisos[/b], se juega que da gusto. Aunque la mayor baza de su jugabilidad [b]es la capacidad de poder detener el tiempo[/b], característica que nos sorprenderá hasta el final del juego por sus posibilidades y con la que podremos hacer auténticas virguerías si la mezclamos posicionándonos bien y planeando nuestros ataques. Otra gran baza [b]son sus jefes, difíciles pero espectaculares[/b]. Cada uno nos brinda [b]un combate muy distinto[/b] y los personajes y sus estilos de combate [b]han sido fielmente representados[/b], me quito el sombrero.

Y por último, toca hablar de su [b]duración[/b], talón de Aquiles habitual en los juegos con tanta acción. El contenido base de Touhou Luna Nights me ha durado [b]una media de 5-6h[/b] y con su contenido tras completar el juego (yendo a por la mayor cantidad de logros), [b]un total de 10h[/b]. Si aplicáis la media euros/horas, quizá os convenga comprarlo de oferta.

[b]Gran spin-off de Touhou, disfrutable tanto si has jugado o no Touhou 6.[/b]

[b]Muy recomendado.[/b]

98391648.review:
The game is a bit short (7-8 hours) and a certainly has flaws. With that said its time freeze mechanic and take on energy management was refreshing. The game's short length meant the game didn't outstay its welcome and hammer me with those flaws to the point where flaws overwhelmed the good side of the game.

[h1]Combat (7/10)[/h1]
The game's combat fluctuates between 5/10 and 10/10.
Jumps and movement in general sometimes feels floaty and combat heavily relies on both and this is one of contributing factors to that fluctuation. 

Combat is about throwing knives and stopping time, but there's another aspect that makes it more fun: energy management. Knives you throw (and skills) use up MP and you can recover it by moving in close to enemies (or even their projectile attacks) and leeching a limited amount of their mana. 
When you stop time, your time meter starts running out and skills/attacks use time meter instead. Leeching becomes easier, but it also gives less MP as portion of it goes to recover time meter.

[b]STARTING EXPERIENCE (7/10)[/b]
The game starts out fairly simple. You throw knives, jump and slow down time (mostly a useless gimmick, really). That's it. It's a great starting point to have, to give players time to adapt to controls and skills, but I thought it was taken too slowly. 

[b]BOSSES (9.5/10)[/b]
As you reach your first boss the game shows it can do a lot more with combat than just "shoot" down enemies that are slowly approaching you. Bosses are where this game shines most of the time, because each boss is kind of like a puzzle. You can freeze them with your time-stopping ability and on some bosses you must know when to stop time. Some bosses spam projectiles at you and by stoping time you leech the energy of those projectiles sometimes doubling or even trippling your time-freezing meter.

[b]MOST OF THE GAME(8/10)[/b]
As you explore most stages the combat is not difficult, but sometimes requires paying attention to avoid damage. I think it's a good spot to be in for "mindless" section of the game, but at the same time, I wish there was just a tiny bit more risk and engagement in there. 

[b]ENDGAME/POST-GAME(5/10)[/b]
Through most of the game enemies can be frozen and/or easily killed if you notice and take action. The game trains you to deal with enemies in that specific way. Then at some point you enter one area and ALL enemies are either immune to time stop, super tanky, sneaky or all 3 of those. It's a huge pacing issue. It's like one moment you're playing a tactical shooter game and next moment you're thrown into bullet hell game.

[h1]Gameplay combat aside (7/10)[/h1]
There's a lot to explore and many items to find. Most items are fairly uneventful (like tiny MP upgrades), but when I found those rare useful ones it made up for all of the bad ones.

At first you simply run around opening new pathways, but later areas start introducing traps, spinning blades and similar things that interact with your time freezing. Those stages are like mini-puzzle areas.

Then there are few stages that take those mini-puzzle areas a bit too far and you have to keep in mind how 3 different traps interact with your time ability as you rush though an area.

[h1]User Interface (4/10)[/h1]
UI is in follows its own style and is very minimalistic. For example: You can see the items you own, but you cannot select them to see their descriptions. Consumables exist, but they are activated as skills. Speaking of skills, you have to roatate through all of them (incl. consumables) to find the one you want.

So yeah, I liked the look, but hated how impractical it is.

[h1] Summary [/h1]
I can recommend this game, because its mechanics offer something no other game does and boss fights are awesome. With that said, don't expect a very polished experience. The game is fine, but it cannot compete with more popular games of the genre in terms of quality.

98175700.review:
The overall presentation is great and the boss fights are really fun, but there are a lot of things which make the moment-to-moment gameplay of this game needlessly frustrating.

For example, in this game, by getting close enough to enemies and projectiles, you can "graze" them, regaining some missing MP and HP. However, this mechanic feels incredibly inconsistent; not every enemy or projectile can be grazed, and there's some sort of limit to the amount you can graze a single enemy or attack. The game doesn't tell you what can be grazed or how much you can graze it, and grazing standard enemies doesn't restore a lot of meter, so this mechanic is incredibly awkward to use outside of the boss fights.

The metroidvania aspect of this game feels pretty half-baked, as well. About half of the progression items you find throughout the game are keys which let you open specific colours of door, which feels pretty underwhelming. The map isn't very useful; items and upgrades aren't marked, nor is there any way for players to mark points of interest manually. Fast travel points are also extremely spread out. These issues make looking for secrets or anything you missed super annoying.

Enemies at the end of the game become complete bullet sponges, which is a problem because your basic attack consumes mana. After fighting a big enemy, you can end up having to stand around for several seconds waiting for your mana to refill.

The game also features a few instances of unfair level design. The most egregious example is the falling chandeliers; the only indication that a chandelier will fall when passing under it is that it has a broken chain. However, most of the chandeliers in the game are placed so that the game's UI partially or completely obscures the chain.

Not a bad game, but not one I'd readily recommend.

98111317.review:
A beautiful game, wholly deserving of its high praise. As any great indie, it is relatively short and very well-polished - the gameplay is built around time stop ability, and there are just enough variations to feel deep yet not overwhelming.

This game is difficult, mind you - mostly in a fair way, leaving you conscious of your shortcomings as the player. It is best seen in bossfights that are all preceded by a checkpoint and a way to recharge health (a welcome feature in a game that will kill you a lot), as the movesets are looped and devoid of RNG aside from certain attack patterns. Just like in Dark Souls (you knew this comparison was coming, didn't you), you get to learn your foe over time, but with the time stop and virtually no distance between the save point and the boss arena you will not waste that time artificially.

There are a few moments of frustration, of course. The game occasionally asks you to retrieve a key item, presenting you with a gauntlet, then asking to backtrack through it to come back out with the item. While a fair challenge, it is one that will often drag out and become boring. Beyond that, certain enemies will knock you off the screen into a different room, resetting themselves, and some are fast and agressive enough to demand a time stop to tackle or skip them. It is a lovely benefit of the core mechanic on its own, but the final level and the bonus stage have a couple infuriating enemy placements, and often close enough to the checkpoint to warrant a reset if you get hit (and you are likely to). And yet, despite the length of this rant, it is justified for the endgame areas, isn't it?

The art and music of the game are above all possible praise - I cannot do them enough justice. It is Touhou, after all. The story is not too far above being just an excuse for the gameplay, though it utilizes the existing characters well - and a person unfamiliar with lore will pick up most important things ("Sakaya is a maid, Patchi has asthma, Marisa is a thief of precious things") quite easily.

To conclude this disproportionate review, this game is gorgeous, worth buying, and worth studying.
Gameplay: 10/10
Art: 10/10
Music: 10/10
Story: 6/10
Total: ⑨/10, strongest game

97687901.review:
A decent metroidvania that has one incredibly well done stand out feature.  The "time stop" mechanic is a masterpiece, and it carries the entire game.  Not only is it intuitive, but surprisingly versatile and can be used for offense, defense, and even recovery.  Words can't describe what a joy it is, and it alone justifies the purchase price.  

Next best feature is the boss fights.  While the "time stop" gameplay is a universal crowd-pleaser, the bosses are love-letters to the original Touhou source material.  Like their counterparts in the original games, the boss fights in Touhou Luna Nights are beautiful, challenging, and require memorization and precision to master.  And in one final flex and nod to the source material, it's possible to no-damage beat all of the bosses without using time stop.  But I don't recommend it though unless you are a bullet-hell fan.

96399617.review:
This game is fantastic. You could not ask anything more from a 2D action platformer.

Describing the game as "Metroidvania" is a little untrue. It's basically all the good parts of a Metroidvania (some branching paths and exploration) but minus all the bad parts that usually entails (so there's no endless backtracking as you swat down the same mooks you've killed a million times already, THANK GOD). It's closer to a 2D side-scroller that allows for a little backtracking. The map is a nice size, not super huge and overly complex like most Metroidvanias.

The best part is that the game doesn't try to artificially inflate the runtime with endless backtracking and wandering around. It's fairly straightforward and always rewards you with new and exciting challenges in every room. I couldn't ask anything more as far as level design goes.

Also, the sprite work is fucking fantastic. You can freeze literally any frame in this game and each character will be doing something badass. This game looks amazing 100% of the time and it's clear the artists put a lot of care into their characters. Speaking of style, I like how the game starts off super Japanese-looking (the first level is a Japanese bathhouse) but then it gradually shifts to a more European aesthetic (European-style castles, libraries, etc.) Hell, the main character is a European-style maid. So the feel of the game is actually quite the fusion, despite the anime aesthetic.

Speaking of characters, I think it was an excellent choice to have the game feature Sakuya instead of Reimu this time. The time-stop mechanic is integrated beautifully into the gameplay. Nothing's more fun than pretending to be Dio as you Za Warudo your enemies and surround them with a death trap of throwing knives.

If there's anything not to love about this game, I'd say that it's the runtime (about 4-5 hours). It's clear they were going for quality over quantity on this one. Of course this is the preferable choice, but the climax and resolution left me wanting more. 

Also, I'd say the difficulty level is extremely low compared to what you would expect from a Touhou game. You can beat most bosses on the second try. Once you obtain Thousand Knives, you can sweep most bosses easily by barraging the enemy with knives during active time, immediately freezing time, collecting graze, and then spamming the enemy with knives in stopped time as well. The game kind of puts the onus on you if you want a more challenging experience (deliberately forgoing certain skills, etc.)

All in all I loved it. I have to say I was truly amazed when the credits rolled and I saw only a handful of people could put together a game as amazing as this. I'll be following Team Ladybug very closely from now on.

96252867.review:
While a short game to beat (3 hours for main game, 2 for post-game content in my playthrough), Luna Nights was a super fun experience from start to finish. It is a love letter to Embodiment of Scarlet Devil and is very faithful to the source material; the characters and dialogue feel perfectly inline with the main series of games. The soundtrack to the game is also purely comprised of remixes from the mainline games, with many tracks being taken straight from EoSD and a couple being borrowed from Imperishable Night and Mountain of Faith.

The game's central mechanic, being able to slow down and stop time at will, is also handled exceptionally. Being able to dodge otherwise undodgeable attacks and setting up tons of knives and watching them pile tons of damage on a boss is incredibly satisfying. By the end of the game I was stopping time and setting up attacks almost as much as I was playing in real time. I'd honestly love to see more games utilize time the way Luna Nights does.

The highlight for me, though, were the boss battles. Attacks are done in the same order every time you fight a boss and there is almost no randomness to how the attacks operate, much like the bullet patterns in a bullet hell. Learning the patterns and finding optimal ways of dealing with them felt like a puzzle at times and finally beating some of the harder bosses was incredibly satisfying.

Overall, a great game for fans of the franchise or Metroidvania fans looking for something different.

95959138.review:
Touhou Luna Nights is a neat package of masterfully woven gameplay that incorporates mechanics from the series it is based on (Touhou) and the games it is inspired by (Symphony of the Night) while also featuring gorgeous pixel art and absolutely fantastic renditions of music tracks from the sources it derives from.

This Touhou entry into the metroidvania genre has you controlling Sakuya, the maid of the Scarlet Devil Mansion who has been suddenly plopped into a replica world of Gensokyo at the whims of her mistress. Robbed of her time manipulation powers, you then play through the game to gain back your abilities in expected metroidvania fashion to confront your mistress and ultimately find out why you've been dropped here.

A lot of the gameplay gimmicks the game will throw at you has to do with Sakuya's ability to slow down or stop time and each level introduces enemies and platforming puzzles that all make good use of this gimmick that increases in difficulty the further you explore the mansion. Couple this with the buttery smooth movement and control you have over Sakuya and you have what culminates into a challenging yet fun and fair game that never felt frustrating.

Although the game can indeed be finished within about 6 hours, the experience I've had with it has been nothing but a delight that I've had no problem with revisiting the game for another playthrough or another run at doing the boss rush mode.

95757417.review:
Okay, so the first thing I have to say is that I am still surprised at the "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews this game has, as I think it should be "Positive" at most.

Having said that, this is one of the few decent Metroidvanias I felt no compulsion to finish - at least not up to the "true" ending. Another area was unlocked after the original final boss, but I had no interest in exploring it and just stopped there. Here are my main points on the game:

- Gameplay is fine
- The overarching story is too bland, even if you are actually interested in the Touhou universe
- Exploration and progression are very limited
- User interface is terrible
- Graphics are decent for pixel art and well animated, but I was surprised to see people saying that it is "incredibly beautiful" or something
- OST is okay, but not memorable

Bottom line is, buy this game only if you are a Touhou fan who cares only for metroidvania gameplay. Oh, but do that only after having played Hollow Knight, Ori, Bloodstained, Valdis Story and such.

Overall, a 6.0/10

93891276.review:
It's pretty fun when it comes to action, but it sucks pretty hard as a Metrovania.
The overall structure is pretty liner, with occasion branching or hidden paths.
It's technically qualified as a Metrovania with some early paths only accessible once certain ability is collected or some event has been done,
But those often require some very boring backtracking, sometimes even re-do platformer challenges that's not fun second time around.
It doesn't feel like I'm "exploring", but just "following" what the game says.
It has a lot of cool time mechanics, but the level layout and structure just doesn't work that well, in context of either Metrovania, platformer or adventure.

That being said, the animation, the music, the Boss fights, and the Touhou-style nonsense dialogue are still fun.
I probably won't bother to finish the game but I don't regret playing it either.

93334799.review:
this game reminded me of how much I love metroidvanias. and games with actually good combat design!

what I love most is that it gives you so many tools yet allows you to use them at your discretion. the game never holds your hand or tells you "hey, you should probably time stop here" or anything. you get to figure things out for yourself, leading to a very satisfying sort of learning process. no strats I came up with felt unviable, and I'm sure many other players found totally different ways to approach certain situations.

difficulty is well-balanced. it's a single fixed difficulty and it never felt deliberately unfair. whenever I struggled I always found ways I could have done better, so progress came rather quickly since I kept learning and growing after each mistake. I felt like a damn pro by the end of this game.

the map is decent too. you don't have to go [i]too[/i] far to find a save/heal/warp point, though backtracking to find missed goodies proved occasionally annoying, especially since some rooms are frustrating to get through, either because of enemy placement, environment design, or both. one or two secrets were also kinda scummy with where they were hidden, but those are kind of a staple of the genre, so I can't necessarily blame this game itself.

I should also say that this game is very accessible to anyone regardless of their knowledge of touhou. I've learned a bit about these characters over time through osmosis from friends, but otherwise I haven't played, watched, or really learned anything of the games. the referential content is pretty laid-back, so it doesn't really feel like you're getting left out too much. 

sadly it is another case of a fantastic game with a depressingly short length. it takes about 6-7 hours for a first run, add another hour or two for 100%. steam achievements add more time, plus there are a couple of extra modes to start new saves for, but other than that there isn't much replayability unless you want to grind for speedruns, do challenge runs, or just want to enjoy the core gameplay some more.

overall this game is stellar! if you enjoy metroidvanias this is a no-brainer purchase.

93314730.review: This game was fantastic from start to finish. As a guy who isn't involved with much Touhou games, I had a great time playing this metroidvania like game. Once you get the hang of the timestop mechanic (which you should trust me) it becomes interesting of how you can combat common enemies and boss fights. Luna Nights also encourages players to get up close and personal with its graze system which if you get close enough and dodge attacks you can gain health back (MP if you freeze time to dodge) but get hit and and the potential HP or MP goes away. The boss fights themselves are no slouch, requiring you to use all tricks you have at your disposal especially with the final and extra bosses. Aside from gameplay, I pretty much enjoyed the sprite work and really enjoyed its soundtrack which is what Touhou games are well known for having. I can safely say you will enjoy this game if you generally like the Touhou IP or just metroidvania games. I look forward to what Team Lady Bug has to offer in the future.

There's already a lot of positive reviews that echo my appreciation for this game, so instead I'll answer a few questions that i had coming into the game-

[h1]Do I need to know what a "Touhou" is to play this game?[/h1]

[b]No.[/b] You ultimately don't need to know anything about Touhou to play this game. This was my first Touhou game, and I had no trouble with it. That being said, I already had an understanding of what Touhou Project is, and I think a basic understanding of the characters/setting really improves game enjoyment. It definitely isn't required, but maybe watch a youtube video or something before playing this game.

[h1]Am I going to be able to beat this game?[/h1]

[b]Likely.[/b] With the exception of the extra boss, I had little trouble getting all achievements. Most bosses will take a few tries to get used to, but time manipulation makes dodging attacks very simple and rewarding. Additionally, the amount of potential grind is near limitless. If struggling with a boss, you can just brute force yourself and grind a few levels. I beat the game around level 30, and the maximum level is 99. I think that this game can be beat by any decent player with enough time.

[h1]Is the game too short?[/h1]

[b]Depends.[/b] After getting all achievements I would say I got my money's worth. 12 hours isn't a ton of time to put into a game, but I enjoyed every minute of it so I almost am happy with its length. Its short length meant I didn't ever get tired of the gameplay, although I certainly could have gotten worn out had the game gone on too long.

Overall, this game is really a must play for anyone who likes metroidvanias or platformers or action games. Please play it
