93087786.review:
[h1] Fun, Challenging Platformer [/h1] 

This is a cute, creative little platformer with lovely pixel art visuals, good music (as expected for a Touhou game) and plenty of clever ideas. As the time-stopping, knife-chucking battle-maid Sakuya, you jump and run and shoot your way through a greatest hits of some of the most recognizable faces of the Touhou mythos (so basically just Embodiment of Scarlet Devil... Not many deep cuts here). The unique core idea to the game is that you can stop and slow time at will during combat and platforming, which leads to a bunch of nifty puzzles and cool combat moments. The way you heal is also a genius adaptation of a mechanic from the source material, in that you regain health by [i] almost [/i] getting hit by enemy attacks.
It's all a lot of fun and keeps every area, enemy and boss feeling very fresh.
The story is fine, though it really assumes some basic familiarity with the setting. It's a pity, since the gameplay is more accessible than the original shmups. Don't let a lack of knowledge put you off if you don't know anything about Touhou, since the game is still fun on it's own, but newcomers to the world will defo be confused...

The biggest criticism you'll see of this game is that it's too short, which is only the case if you're really good at 2D platformers, or if you go in expecting a massive 30 hour Metroidvania. I took about 9 hours to beat it and I feel like I got my money's worth. If you're a dab hand at this type of game, you might feel a bit cheated though...
Much of the playtime was due to the challenge, especially some of the later bosses. It's not an easy game at all, though it's not any kind of ballbusting Kaizoid hell-game either.
My biggest complaint is that the game isn't very good as a metroidvania. Backtracking through the tough later levels to find a breakable wall you missed is no fun, even if those levels were enjoyable the first way round. It's more of a linear arcade platformer with light backtracking and missable upgrades.

All round, this is a great little title. Small, but perfectle proportioned in every way.
Give it a shot!

Bought this game and played it over the weekend, really fun metroidvania, albeit pretty short if you're jamming through it to the end. The combat is really fun and the time mechanics are really cool, especially with how they are implemented in boss fights. It's a Touhou game so the music is really good.

The main issues I have with the game personally are the way the dash mechanic is implemented and some enemy placements. There are several rooms in the game where trying to rush through will cause you to get hit by an enemy and get launched back into the previous room. It's not a major problem in the game but just kind of annoying given that this game feels very much like a speed game. The dash mechanic very much feels like an after thought, and it controls very weird. Can't say much for keyboard controls, I played with an Xbox controller, but double tapping in a given direction felt very clunky when you're constantly moving around the screen in different directions.

Overall, cool game.

92668258.review:
This game kinda bangs. 

My familiarity with the Touhou franchise is basically Night of nights and Cirno and even with just that I had a helluva a good time playing this game. The gameplay is tight and responsive and the grazing system combined with basic attacks taking mana introduces a super fun risk reward style of gameplay which sets it apart from other games in the genre. Sprite art is absolutely gorgeous even when blown up on a big screen and conveys all the needed information without cluttering the screen. Music is only bops and features my favourite trope of the characters/main theme playing in the final battle. The bosses are all fantastic and incredibly enjoyable to fight and that perfect level of challenging but not too difficult to become frustrating.

The cons though are the game is incredibly short which by the price tag and seemingly very small team isn't that much of a surprise however its still kind of a bummer. The level design leaves something to be desired making the game overall feel more like an action platformer than a proper metroidvania. Enemy hit boxes can be a little ambiguous which makes it difficult to properly gauge where you can safely graze (thankfully not a problem in bosses) and the game itself doesn't really play around enough with the time stop and slow down mechanics, only really exploring it at the end game. 

The story I'm not really qualified to talk about too much as again I know Cirno and night of nights and that's my touhou knowledge but from an outsider perspective it's mediocre at best and seems to just exist to push bosses at you and progress the game but that's fine. 

Overall games great can recommend; one of the better modern metroidvanias.

8/10

92015140.review:
Just finished the game and all optional bosses, and I'm already sad there's no more of the game left to play.  Touhou Luna Nights is an incredibly fun and energetic metroidvania. The combat system is so fast and frenzied, but also requires precision and control to ensure you don't run out of MP (the energy that allows you to attack).  Luckily you can absorb this by "grazing" nearby enemies.  Combined with being able to temporarily slow and stop time, I loved every moment of action in this game.

The atmosphere was also pleasant, with colorful scenery and a soundtrack to get you pumped up for battle.  I'm not at all familiar with the backstory as this was my first foray into the Touhou world, but I enjoyed the storyline nonetheless.  Ultimately everything had a lighthearted feel.

Be aware that this game does NOT shy away from difficult bosses, especially toward the end of the game.  There is no difficulty setting, nor a way of fumbling your way through the last few battles. The bosses have very definite patterns, and you will have to 100% learn those patterns to defeat them. However, Touhou Luna Nights does it perfectly - the first fight, you feel there's no hope of ever defeating them. The next few fights you start to see the ways of getting around each attack. And after a few more fights, you can replay the battle as much as you want and never get hit.  

I can only think of a couple things that I wish the game did differently.  One, though I would definitely classify this as a metroidvania (there are at least 4-5 different environmental obstacle types that require powerups to pass), I wish there were more.  But, I think that relates more to the second issue - the game is too short! But I think that's a testament to how good it is.  It's so much fun to play, you're sad when it's all over and wish there was another 10 hours of game play.

Though short, Touhou Luna Nights is totally worth the money though, especially if you love fast paced metroidvanias. Glad I gave this one a try!

Again, it's definitely not a bad game, and I expect most people will like it. It just didn't click for me.

91555816.review:
Quality of story: If you're familiar with the main Touhou series, the characters and plot are pretty much on-par. (If you aren't, tbere's enough exposition you should at least understand what you're doing and why at all points, although some details - like just why it's raining and just what the significance of that is - might remain elusive.) It could plausibly have been a side-story at some point in canon Gensokyo history. And if there isn't an actual tea party displayed in an ending, there's at least the presumption that tea - and company to go with it - shall be forthcoming.

The audiovisuals: The music's mostly well-made versions of character and location leitmotifs Touhou players will immediately recognize. Obviously good, though if you're not the speedrunning type some of the higher-energy pieces might feel a bit tiring after a quarter-hour on the same song. The art is good: the animation does a good job of characterizing everybody, and there's notably a good use of particle-type physics to handle water (which matters here) and knives, among other things.

The game balance: Not too easy, never too vicious. Like other attempts to convert things from top-down free flight into a platformer, everybody's ridiculous offensive abilities are toned down enough to make the game playable, and when necessary bosses are "extended onto" to better telegraph their attacks. You have health instead of lives, scarce yet sufficient checkpoints and healing stations, and two stat systems which are balanced so that you can get through the game smoothly without ever actually having to think about grinding, but grindable to make up for minor deficiencies in player finesse. (The game, even in in-universe terms, is designed to be "winnable".) There are a few weirdnesses in the layout of the game resources and balances, but they're minor and have explanations in the setting, if not obvious ones.

You're playing as Sakuya Izayoi, and for Touhou fans that's going to be a major attraction of the game. [u]It fulfills this premise.[/u] While you won't have everything available from the start, you start out with some of your knife collection and able to fight, glide if not fly, and indefinitely survive underwater. You can manually recover thrown knives (for a refund of some of the mana you spent to throw them) or not; Sakuya's ability to almost reflexively recollect them out of spacetime as needed is preserved. The game implements a version of the main series' grazing mechanic: finesse at avoiding most attacks means you'll steal power out of them, and most enemies and many boss attacks let you recover health as well if you're good enough.While the spell cards (sub-attacks) you'll acquire during the game are also greatly toned down from their original out-of-game versions, they're all fun to use and none are outright necessary (scored boss rush after completing the game excepted, and that only for the achievements). I especially enjoyed playing with the two not-quite-knives added into this game, one of which is a "why hasn't Sakuya been using this thing all along?" and one of which makes perfect sense to be there given the setting, plot and characters involved but again is something you might not have seen coming.

And yes, you'll regain Sakuya's power to mess with time. And yes, while you're in a place which can still find ways to challenge you (after all, the cast knows what you can do), this is just as abusable as anybody could hope for. It's not quite balanced, but this is also part of the fun. The game does a good job of making diverse ways your power interacts with the environment without making the power itself fiddly to use. It makes traversing the game world interesting without usually ever reaching the frustrating stage. (And if your dreams of playing as Sakuya included throwing a knife, stopping time and using the airborne knife as a platform, yes. So much yes.)

In terms of combat, well, yes. You can do every brutal and unfair trick you'd expect. That said, you don't have to (again, getting achivements off the post-game boss rush is an exception). There are creatures who are a nuisance to fight "fairly", and there are boss attacks which will be very hard to cleanly avoid without at least slowing time down at points or having movement abilities that shouldn't be unlocked on your first meeting (and this game doesn't really do anything to encourage sequence breaking). But if you prefer to elegantly and perfectly duel as a maid, you're covered.

All in all, this is everything I could have hoped for given the premise of the game. I don't think it's perfect (some of the music tracks could have benefited from longer arrangements, a few tiny details like can physics aren't quite perfected for playing with and now that I know the full story, a couple elements in the timeline don't quite mesh without any of the usual explanations for why really working), but it's certainly worth its original purchase price and probably sets a standard for Touhou platformers.

91253677.review:
After 100% the map I have come to the conclusion that this game is fucking brilliant. At no point did I feel like the design wasn't as good and consistent as the rest of the game. But that's not to say this game is without flaws.

Despite being a metroidvania this game is very linear. You have to defeat the bosses in a very set order, and the only real metroidvania quality it has is having to backtrack once you get new abilities to get new items and other unlockables. I felt this game was a massive weak point and let me down a decent bit. 

But, the game more than makes up for where it lacks, because man I've not had this much fun just progressing in a metroidvania as I had with this game. Usually its the destination the matters, the adventure. But this game every enemy is a treat to fight due to its brilliant combat system.

Its greatly built around the MP bar and your time meter, to throw knifes it uses MP unless time is frozen then it takes away from your time remaining until it unfreezes. Your MP regenerates over time very slowly, so if you want it back faster then you have to get close to the enemy and graze their attacks to regen MP. It also recovers HP providing a very daring high risk high reward gameplay style.

The ability to stop time is very fun to play about with and with the different special attacks presented to you your options for sandbox are absolutely insane. Coupled with the fact that with good knowledge of the map and good platforming you can chain your time to last for insane amounts of time and get very high rewards for having a deep understanding of the game and environment. If you know a section of the map and need to quickly get around there is no need for tedious fighting against enemies you've already fought, freeze time and run right past them. However, the balance to this is if you don't know the layout and don't know where the enemies are you will run out of time very fast and find yourself surrounded with no means of defence, so don't get greedy without knowledge of the situation. 

The boss fights are the strongest part of the game, each fight felt extremely well polished and greatly enjoyable. It incorporates bullet hell elements and showers down projectiles like the mainline games. This especially shines in the final boss-fight and makes for a very challenging and adrenaline filled fight. It has a good balance of well choreographed attacks and having to learn patterns making a fun experience that doesn't keep you fighting till you're no longer having fun. 

The playtime is rather short, upon writing this review I have completed the game bonus level and all and gotten every item. I have also explored the map but for some odd reason the achievement wont unlock. However, for a £14 game its well worth the price as each hour will be as good as the last

In short, buy this bloody game

91179794.review:
Big thanks to one of my Steam friends for randomly gifting this game to me a few months back! I've had my eyes on this for a while and having the pleasure of experiencing it finally was a treat. The short & simple version of this review is - I enjoyed my time with it and found great enjoyment out of it. Should you get it? If you're looking for a new challenging metroidvania platformer themed around Touhou - definitely! Full price or not - this game is worth a play.

To those who want something more detailed - read on!

[h1]Story:[/h1]
Touhou Luna Nights' story is definitely leaning on the simpler side of things. It's rather straightforward and for the most part - it's out of your way during gameplay. The basic premise is interesting though, playing as Sakuya in a fake version of the Scarlet Devil Mansion made by Remilia. I appreciate it being there as something to drive the player forward and continue progressing as it gives you a clear and defined goal. The character interactions between areas are pretty entertaining, although this is one area this game falls apart in I feel - it's not very friendly with those who aren't Touhou fans with references & dialogue that will just fly over most players' heads if they aren't already acquainted with Touhou in general.

For the record it isn't a dealbreaker - you can enjoy the game just fine as is without necessarily being a Touhou fan but I just kinda wish the interactions between major characters were more...obvious to a newbie sometimes. Still, even not accounting for that - it's still entertaining stuff & easy to follow along with pacing most players will find comfortable enough.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The meat & potatoes of Touhou Luna Nights is really solid. The way this game plays is really good. There is a lot of stuff to take in and I feel as though the early-game is really tough as you need to properly adjust to all the mechanics. The main gimmick of Touhou Luna Nights is being able to stop time - early on you're given a clock & given the meter at the top of the screen you can freeze & unfreeze time as you please. That's oversimplifying it but the entire game is built around the premise of you having to either freeze or slow down time to get things going and that leads to some exhilarating puzzle-solving sometimes. Another fairly important thing you'll be doing in this game is a thing called Graze - getting close to an enemy either to restore your HP or your MP & Time Gauge. The former is for when time isn't frozen and the latter is for when time is frozen. This is one mechanic I found incredibly finicky to get working consistently unless I freeze time as it's never clear how close you are supposed to be to the enemy. Sometimes they can be social-distancing from you and you still trigger a graze, other times it feels like you have to smash your face into them to trigger it - it's incredibly inconsistent and I never really found it reliable, except during boss battles.

The difficulty of the game is something else though. I won't say it's the most difficult thing out there - quite far from it, I've certainly played harder games, but Touhou Luna Nights definitely isn't an easy game. It WILL kick your ass, especially during boss battles. I won't spoil the characters if you haven't already spoiled them for yourself, but the boss battles are going to be your true test of skill and they will lean heavily on trial & error gameplay. That's not to say the rest of the game isn't hard though - it is. There's a lot of things in the general level design that will test your ability to utilize time & general acrobatics, although this is one area I feel this game falls apart in a little bit. Sometimes you'll encounter corridors of nothing but holding either left or right and the entire room is just filled with enemies. This is particularly problematic towards the end of the game and it just feels incredibly lazy.

Control-wise I didn't really have that much of an issue playing it although having to readjust to some...interesting default controls was a little bit tough. For context - I used a PS4 controller to play this game, so for me - X was shoot, square was to stop time & circle was to jump. Pretty weird for me to adjust to given how other metroidvanias have it basically the complete opposite of that. It is possible to rebind the controls though so it's not really an issue. The controls are rock-solid despite this - they don't feel slippery or imprecise though knockback on getting hit is incredibly annoying and you'll have to be dealing with it a lot. Aside from that - they're pretty good.

[h1]Graphics, Music & Optimization:[/h1]
The game has a very distinct pixel-art style to it and I genuinely can't get enough of it - this game looks great and nails the look flawlessly. Each environment has a satisfying amount of depth to it & the character art is also done really well. Nothing really stands out as being egregious & the animations are also really fluid. It's obvious there's been a lot of love & care put into the game's art and glancing at everything there's going to be one or two details that will stand out.

In terms of music - the game mostly has rearranges of Touhou themes & they sound great. While I can't exactly say some of the themes "fit" certain areas, I'm glad that the music filling in the explorable areas is great. It doesn't disappoint in any sense, especially the character-specific themes during boss battles. Get the soundtrack if you have the spare cash for it, it's a treat to listen to! In terms of sound design there's not a lot I can comment on. It serves its purpose and it's not terribly outstanding.

Optimization-wise this game has no issues. I haven't encountered any during my 8+ hour playthrough, even when it came to 144hz+ compatibility - the game runs absolutely flawlessly with no stutters or framerate dips or any graphical issues to speak of so it gets a solid pass from me.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
I recommend Touhou Luna Nights as a purchase. For $15 you definitely get your money's worth in a fun metroidvania Touhou platformer. With a challenging difficulty curve, great music & amazing pixel art graphics Touhou Luna Nights is a game worth purchasing, despite its shortcomings with level design & finicky mechanics.

91162976.review:
[h1][b]Time-Stopping Chief Maid’s Bizarre Adventure[/b][/h1]
Touhou is a franchise with long history as it keeps introducing and expanding fan community around the world by games, music, or other media. Touhou Luna Nights (TLN) is a one example of fan popularity which I think it’s worth knowing its origin before actual review.

[Quote][h1]So, What’s Touhou?[/h1]
In short, Touhou Project is a franchise of 2D vertically-scrolling danmaku (or bullet hell games), originally has created by single person known as “Zun” (programming, art, music) since 1995. Touhou story mainly sets in the sanctuary of gods, spirit, fairy, and youkai called “Gensokyo”, isolated from real world. Each story is self-contained and involve incident where shiner maiden has to resolve by beating up the culprit. Each incident always ends up peacefully by “Spellcard Rules” as it keeps youkai in control without casualty or destroying balance of Gensokyo.

Even Touhou ownership is retained by Zun, he freely allows and encourage fan product as long as they respectfully follow his guidelines.[/quote]

[h1]Another Day, Another Incident[/h1]
TLN is a Metroidvania Touhou fangame developed by indie Team Ladybug. Unlike most of Touhou games which player usually plays as Shrine Maiden, player will take full control of “Sakuya Izayoi” (an elegant chief maid who serves under vampire sisters named Remilia and Flandre Scarlet of Scarlet Devil Mansion).

The incident takes place in a parallel Scarlet Devil Mansion where Sakuya’s power is stripped away. Sakura shortly finds out that the space is created by her own mistress for amusement. She has to acquire her power back (ability to manipulate time) and find the way back to real Gensokyo.
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2428156579[/url]
Similar to most Touhou games, TLN has self-contained story that involve one particular incident, but doesn’t take anything way too serious. Even non-Touhou fans can still enjoy both story and interesting characters as the game occasionally introduce throughout the game from engineer kappa, Nitori to magician, Marisa. Each character shares a bit personality, ability, and background that respect original vision of creator. Some have fewer screenplays that demands newcomers to know more.

[h1]Maid on the Run[/h1]
Speaking of Metroidvania, TLN follows similar gameplay and map design like Super Metroid, but comes with its own gimmick of Touhou setting. You will navigate through platforming in different environments ranged from temple area to gothic mansion complex. The map is much more compact and simple, but full of detail and layout are mostly distinct of each other. The game also marks notification to help player keep track their progression via ESC menu.

I will come across various types of enemy and platforming that will test your combination of skills, reflex, and timing. The exploration also rewards the upgrades like max health, extent ability gauge, and unlocks new moves / skills that you can revisit and reach hidden room.

The interconnection between areas, Torii gate (fast travel), and overall pacing make in-game traversal feel enjoyable and less tedious.

[h1]TIME, Sakuya? Is it really that TIME again?[/h1]
Sakuya’s signature weapon is her throwing knifes. Every attack consumes Sakuya MP gauge. The combat focuses on ranged weapon while managing MP and avoiding touching damage. Later, you’ll be introduced to Sakuya’s eternal clock (pocket watch). This tool play major role in both combat and platforming puzzle. She can stop “TIME” and resume as long as TIME gauge doesn’t run out. During TIME stop, the gauge slowly depletes depends on amount of action you perform, but it replenishes overtime or gain by “Graze” system.

TIME stop expands the variety of level gimmicks and creativity that will engage players to observe environment and adapt. For example: some objects / traps only react when TIME stops as you need to carefully plan to use skill and get through, stop TIME to burst your knife damage at once or reverse some boss projectiles, and more creativity.

Moreover, you can also hold attack button to enter “Snail Time” which basically slow time for a couple seconds. It’s useful alternate beside main power and solves some tricky puzzles.

[h1]Graze, Graze, Graaaze![/h1]
“Graze” in Touhou refers to the concept of moving player close to enemy hitbox / projectile to gain bonus score. In TLN, Sakuya will recover gauge based on TIME condition.
- She recovers HP, MP and TIME while grazing in real time.
- She slightly recovers MP and TIME while grazing in TIME stop.
Graze system is high-risk high-reward mechanic that engage offensive playstyle and memorize set of attack sequence. Especially boss fights where they are ruthless and throw everything at you, but fairly telegraphed and definitely the most fun aspect of the game
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2428157812[/url]
On the other hand, graze and TIME stop in TLN is one of most generous system in Touhou games. It keeps your survivability as long as you learn where to position Sakuya and prepare for incoming attack. Amount of projectile in TIME stop also greatly affect MP recovery rate, allows you to continue flow of normal / special attack loop.

I personally think the design is balanced and intend to support accessibility of average players while encouraging perfect / challenge play for hardcore Touhou fan. You can even beat most bosses without using TIME and special attack.

[h1]Progression / Extra Contents[/h1]
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2428156509[/url]
Defeating enemy will grant you experience point and jewels which are used to convert into in-game money in Nitori shop for consumable items and upgrade. Character progression is straightforward where your stats slightly increase on every level and manually saved on phonebooth. The level cap is 99, but there is no point to grind to maximum. Beyond Lv.40-50 with mastering graze, you’re pretty much untouchable maid. 

TLN also offers extra stage featuring two secret bosses and boss rush mode which unlock after you complete main story and extra mode respectively. It could take around 7-10 hours for 100% completion depended on your pacing.

[h1]Audio / Soundtrack[/h1]
Audio and sound effects are pretty solid as it gives strong arcade vibe. Touhou music is originally combination of various music genres by ZUN. It’s hard to describe because Touhou music is very broad, full of modern electronics to traditional magical folk with emotional shift in tone and melody.

TLN uses remix version boss themes from main Touhou games. More upbeat and tone shifting while preserve original tracks respectfully. It overall creates music variation that not just represents character background, but also surprisely sense of enjoyment, excitement, and refreshing.

[h1]Graphics / Performance / Flaws[/h1]
TLN is powered by Mogura Engine 2 which is in-house Engine developed in GameMaker Studio 2. It features beautiful details and fluid pixel art along with colorful visual assets. It has very low PC requirement and stable performance without any crashes or game-breaking bugs.

My only complaint is startup option only recognizes default key even they are changed in main settings. Startup / graphical option also should be pair in main menu. 

[h1]Closing[/h1]
TLN somehow reminds me of another Touhouvania - Koumajou Densetsu (2009), but more dynamic and friendly system. 

TLN is a memorable fun experience and love letter to Metroidvania crafted by people who adore Touhou universe and heartily want to share similar experience to newcomers in different form of gameplay. It also reminds me how large and dedication of Touhou community around the world influenced by one man work. Highly recommend!

88745132.review:
I hundo'd this game within a week, which goes to show how short this game is. Even then, Touhou Luna Nights is absolutely worth your money and your time.

This is the first Touhou game I've ever played, so I have little knowledge of the characters or the world outside of the occasional doujinshi. The story isn't anything to write home about; it's standard fantasy fare without any heavy topics or deep life lessons. Barring that, everything else was simply fantastic.

The art from the character designs to the environments was genuinely great. The enemies were diverse and interesting to fight with almost no copy-paste content. The bosses were all phenomenal and the time slow and stop abilities, coupled with the "graze" mechanic ties the combat all together. While we're at it, let's put in some banger renditions of the coveted Touhou soundtrack to complete the package.

There are a few nitpicks I have though. There are some parts of the movement that I'm not an absolute fan of, such as pressing crouch and jump causing the slide attack instead of simply doing crouch and attack. Graze can also be a bit too rewarding, especially when coupled with some especially strong abilities, namely Thousand Dagger, but you can find that out on your own time. As mentioned before, the story isn't anything special and the game's length is pretty short. That being said, none of these problems greatly take away from the game at all.

Luna Nights is a small, yet radiant nugget of gold among the many competitors of the indie game market. As someone who is comparatively impartial to the Touhou series, this game's quality is astonishing to say the least, and deserves every ounce of praise that it has received. I look forward to any new releases that this developer may make in the future.

This game has the following:

- Unique and interesting game mechanics
- Fun time-related puzzle platforming
- Challenging bosses
- Amazing music

This game does not have that double back and explore new area feel that metroidvania's generally have. The game's progress is very linear, with only a few small items needing the player to revisit older areas and you never really need to go back to old areas to progress. I don't really hold it against the game though, more or less hold it against Steam's tagging. Having a room-based map does not a metroidvania make.

The game is pretty short, beating the main game will run you around 8 hours or so depending on how good you are at taking down the bosses. Getting S rank in boss rush mode will likely take you a little while longer, but by that point you'll probably have figure'd out the easiest way to deal with bosses is by using 1000 of your daggers thrown at them faster than Sakuya's enemy can blink. Enjoy the game, it's fun! Worth the price, and I'll be looking forward to more titles from this developer in the future.

86562742.review:
Luna Nights takes place in an imaginary world created by Remilia Scarlet out of boredom or whatever. As her maid Sakuya, you get sucked into the world and your objective is to brutally murder as many Touhous as you can. There's not a ton of plot to delve into. The pixel art is gorgeous and animates smoothly, and the detailed backgrounds add a lot of character to the game. The soundtrack has the familiar frenetic Touhou sound, with hints of Michiru Yamane's grandiose Castlevania work. It's personally not my favorite, but it never got on my nerves either. 

You attack in Luna Nights by throwing knives, which expends MP. As such your attacks are limited, but this is where it gets interesting. Much like grazing bullets in shmups, Luna Nights' first core mechanic allows you to graze enemies/projectiles to earn more MP/HP. I was hesitant at first - it reminded me of Secret of Mana's dogshit combat where you have to attack then turtle to refill your attack gauge. Now that I'm writing, I realize Luna Nights is kind of the inverse of that idea. Either way, it works out brilliantly. Combat becomes a balance of risk-reward in an idea similar to Bloodborne, where attacking immediately after you lose HP gives you a chance to earn it back. Playing aggressively is essential. Luna Nights' second core mechanic is freezing time. When time is frozen you can still attack, but your knives suspend in air until time continues. Instead of spending MP your attacks lower the time gauge, but you can earn this back either naturally or by grazing while time is frozen. You also have a limit to how many knives you can throw so you can't just murder bosses within seconds (thought it's pretty effective on common enemies). Attributes like HP, MP, and the amount of knives you can throw during frozen time can either be bought or found by exploring the map and breaking fake walls. You can also find special secondary skills that function like Castlevania subweapons, but they take up MP instead of having a separate meter. At first I stuck to the homing knives, but I became partial to the chainsaw arc-projectile near the end. You can switch between them on the fly which allows you to experiment a little.

Speaking of bosses, they're top-notch. There are only six overall (with a bonus seventh and eighth) but I enjoyed them all immensely. They take a few minutes to beat and at first I thought they dragged on a bit too long for my tastes, but it ended up adding to the tension. Each boss has a cycle of 3-4 unique attacks on top of a stronger attack they get when you whittle their HP down enough. The patterns are fairly simple but keeping calm and dodging consistently is the real trick. Fighting regular enemies is also fun, but not nearly as great as the boss battles. I think Team Ladybug realized this as instead of brainless corridors full of enemies they add a lot of clever platforming segments that require freezing time. As the game progresses you encounter hazards/platforms that react differently to frozen time - moving in reverse, moving regardless of time, and only moving when time is stopped. You also unlock new abilities that add to the platforming - some genre staples like double-jumping and sliding, but also really cool moves like using your knives as platforms while time is stopped. None of the platforming is too tricky but it goes a long way to adding variety to the game. The game itself is roughly 5-6 hours depending on how good you are. I understand it's better to end on a high note instead of overstaying your welcome (and the final boss battle is a very high note) but I still found myself wanting more. I think the game had enough momentum to support an extra hour or two of gameplay to tidily wrap things up; however I did enjoy every single minute of what I played.

Luna Nights is absolutely worth the hype, and it's a steal at $18. I definitely have Team Ladybug on my radar now. Their next game is based on Record of Lodoss War and looks functionally similar to Luna Nights with more of an RPG emphasis. It's still in Early Access so I'll wait on it to get the full experience. In the meantime I'll play through Luna Nights' postgame boss fights and check out the SMT game Team Ladybug did.

86464030.review:
I absolutely love this game and its one of the few examples I've seen of a "nearly perfect" game. I say "nearly perfect" because there are a small number of tiny little nitpick issues that are more personal gripes than actual problems, and when I say small I mean I can count them on one hand. They're so insubstantial I won't bother going over them.

If you are a fan of the metroid/castlevania style games, you want this game. If you really like the Touhou universe, especially the characters, scenery, and music from Embodiment of Scarlet Devil, you want this game. The unique mechanics they included are brilliant and just really fun to use. The fact that even your basic attacks are tied to MP means you have to think and plan your attacks instead of just mashing wildly. The mechanics of slowing down/stopping time and how the world and attacks interact with that power make for some really interesting moments. Better yet, bosses can actually be defeated without using any of the time manipulation powers, though it is significantly harder.

The grazing mechanic brought over from official Touhou games is genius as well. Getting extremely close to either an enemy or bullet without getting hit will cause a "graze" and allow you to actually regenerate HP and MP. This mechanic is necessary as otherwise there is no good way to heal on the go, and just waiting for your MP to regen passively can take quite some time. Using the slow time ability can help get more grazes in a pinch, but stopping time changes how it works. While time is stopped, attacks and enemies can only be grazed a limited number of times. Grazing a frozen object is easy, so it only regenerates MP and a bit of your TIME gauge which is spent by doing any actions while time is stopped. A lot of mid/late game bosses can actually be quite challenging if you don't rely on the graze mechanic.

There is a shop to buy items from, but as the game explains you don't just earn the gold needed to buy them from defeating enemies. Instead enemies drop gemstones which you can then sell for gold to buy items. However, the gemstones have a secondary use, granting you very small boosts depending on the type of gemstone. So at times you have to make a choice on if you want to maintain all of your beneficial effects or buy one of the upgrades from the store.

There are a variety of passive abilities and even active "spell cards" that you can find around the world. Movement is smooth and tight, a majority of the enemies are unique, the bosses are amazing and even follow a mostly standard Touhou style progression.

I enjoyed this game so much I've played through the entire thing about 3 times and its one on a short list of games I've completed 100%. And even though I already collected and beat everything in this game I still wanna go back and play through the whole thing again.

85958951.review:
[h1][b]Reseña Corta[/b][/h1]

Luna Nights es un 10/10, tienen un OST increible, una jugabilidad magnifica, un diseño de niveles muy bueno y un -posiblemente- aun mejor diseño de enemigos. Innova bastante en el genero de los metroidvanias, bebe mucho de la saga principal de los Touhou y el genero de los bullet hell lo cual resulta en una serie de mecanicas muy interesantes y bien implementadas. Habiendo conseguido todos los logros del juego puedo decir que lo he disfrutado en cada momento y seguramente lo seguire jugando para exprimir aun mas la diversion que ofrece el titulo.

[h1][b]Reseña Larga[/b][/h1]

[hr] [/hr]

[b]Puntos [strike]negativos[/strike]:[/b]
Touhou Luna Nights es un título que muchas veces se cataloga como un metroidvania lo cual, si bien es cierto, puede generar idea equivocada del juego que veo necesaria aclarar. La obra es totalmente lineal, la exploracion se relega a ser una manera de volver por items que nos han quedado en zonas ocultas y no en una manera de conseguir que el jugador decida, en cierta medida, cual sera la secuencia del juego como suele ser usual en los exponentes de este genero. Esto no es un problema en lo mas minimo pero es necesario advertir a quienes esten esperando un juego que les de cierta libertad para decidir sobre el orden de los sucesos. 
Tiene una duracion muy reducida, aproximadamente 5 - 8 horas de juego, lo cual puede ser un problema para muchos.
La historia es meramente un complemento y pasa totalmente a un segundo plano, si estas buscando un juego con una narrativa extensa y desarrollada Luna Nights no es lo que buscas.

[hr][/hr]

[b]Puntos positivos:[/b]
La jugabilidad es excelente, supieron implementar perfectamente las mecanicas del manejo del tiempo no solo en las peleas sino tambien a la hora de interactuar con el entorno y los propios ataques de Sakuya. Su punto más debil es que la mecanica inicial de ralentizar el tiempo se queda obsoleta muy rapidamente, putualmente en el momento que obtenemos el reloj para detener el tiempo, y queda relegada a servir como un medio para resolver uno o dos puzzles más adelante.
La mecanica del Graze incentiva al jugador a ser mas agresivo es sus acciones y a exponerse ataques enemigos si quiere ganar HP/MP, caso contrario se vera en una situacion donde no pueda atacar y se vera sobrepasado por los continuos ataques enemigos.
Los jefes, probablemente lo mas importante debido al estilo de juego que nos propone esta entrega, estan muy bien logrados. Cada uno se siente muy unico y tienen una dificultad bien escalonada. Las batallas son muy entretenidas y son lo suficientemente dificiles en general aunque personalmente hubiera deseado una pelea mas de una dificultad mucho mayor ya que siento que falta ese jefe de una dificultad MUY elevada.
La banda sonora el juego es de una calidad espectacular, muchas de las canciones salen casi directamente de titulos de la saga, como Imperishable Night, por lo que si conocen los OST de la misma sabran de la calidad que estamos hablando.
El apartado visual es simple pero hermoso, los escenarios y los personajes poseen un estilo de arte pixelart muy interesante y llamativa. No hace falta decir que estan basados en una tematica netamente oriental. Los efectos tambien estan bien logrados, la lluvia, el movimiento de los estanques de agua, etc.

[hr][/hr]

En sintesis, Luna Nigths es una entrega muy recomendable que tiene muchos más aciertos que errores. Ademas tiene un precio muy accesible, nada mejor que un juego muy bueno y barato. Pro plus: tiene a Sakuya y a Reimu, tremendas waifus.

85757095.review:
I had glossed over this game originally due to the title.  "Touhou?  That's that series of bullet-hell shooters right?  Eh, I'm alright."
It wasn't until I tried the GLORIOUS MASTERPIECE that is Record of Lodoss War: Wonder Labyrinth that I took another look at the developer, Team Ladybug, which brought be back to this.  Seeing that it was a Metroidvania, and knowing what Team Ladybug is capable of when it comes to Metroidvanias, I bought it immediately.  I'm glad I did.  There's a lot in common between this and Wonder Labyrinth.  Both games ooze quality. Both games are beautiful with tight controls and nice, smooth animations at 60 fps.  The time stop mechanic makes for some interesting action puzzle solving amidst the more straightforward action metroidvania-ing.  You also have to pretty carefully manage your MP, because each attack consumes MP, and once you're out that's it.  You can no longer attack.  Thankfully you can restore your MP via vending machines and a "graze" mechanic that reminds me of certain bullet-hell shooters that give you bonuses for getting close to enemies and projectiles.

I 100% recommend Touhou Luna Nights for any fans of Metroidvanias or quality video games in general.  I've had much worse experiences with games 3x the price that cost several orders of magnitude more to develop.  Team Ladybug is a absolute treasure.

85371063.review:
[h1] Touhou Luna Nights, un metroidvania bonito, desafiante y original [/h1]

Touhou Luna Nights es un metroidvania que tiene un fuerte enfoque en el combate, la acción del mismo, la exploración y con unos pequeños toques de RPG.
Todo gira en torno a la mecánica de ralentizar y detener el tiempo, aunque sea por un tiempo limitado puede sonar a que el juego es bastante fácil así (Yo lo veía así), lo sería si es que detenemos el tiempo en un juego que no está diseñado para eso, en cambio este está completamente diseñado para sacarle todo el provecho y explotar de diferentes maneras la novedosa mecánica. Además, ¿no es genial detener el tiempo y llenar de cuchillos a nuestro enemigo?

[h1] ¿Cómo se juega? [/h1]

En general, se utiliza la mecánica de detener el tiempo y ralentizar el tiempo para resolver puzzles que parecen imposibles, pasar zonas llenas de trampas y derrotar jefes y enemigos, estos últimos pudiendo ser algo injustos, pero con su mérito, ya que bueno, ¿mencioné que podemos manipular el tiempo?, obligándonos así a sacarle todo el provecho que podamos a nuestros poderes.
Su desafío es bastante moderado, no es fácil pero tampoco es muy difícil y perder nunca me resultó frustrante en ningún momento, es cuestión de ir aprendiéndose los enemigos y adaptarse al juego. Estoy seguro de que van a morir un par de veces antes de lograr derrotar a algún jefe. Además de que el juego tiene sus puntos de guardado increíblemente bien medidos. Es un juego bastante justo en cuanto a dificultad.
Hay que mencionar que el juego premia muy bien a la gente que es curiosa y que explora los niveles, con mejoras de salud, maná y nuevos ataques especiales. No es realmente un juego complicado y es bastante lineal, pero no del todo, siempre que queramos podemos volver a anteriores zonas para explorar lugares a los que antes no podíamos acceder, como todo buen metroidvania. De todos modos, es un juego que sabe mantener increíblemente bien el ritmo y pocas veces (por no decir nunca) nos vamos a sentir perdidos. 

[h1] ¿Cómo se siente? [/h1]

Me gustaría destacar su hermosa banda sonora, la cual son todas reinterpretaciones de temas de los juegos originales, con nuevos instrumentos y con ciertos efectos que la hacen sonar modernizada, lo cual no le queda nada mal y diría que hasta me parecen mejores que las originales. Pero entiendo que haya gente a la que le parezca taladrante.
Igual le quiero le quiero reconocer méritos a su apartado artístico, con ese pixelart tan de moda con personajes muy bonitos, bien animados y coloridos al igual que los enemigos y escenarios. Aparte de gozar un muy bonito apartado artístico no pide nada de requisitos, así que tu patata con dos cables lo va a poder mover sin drama. 2x1

[h1] ¿Qué tal la historia? [/h1]

No quiero hablar mucho sobre la historia, ya que juega un papel muy importante en la conexión entre ''juego'' e ''historia'', intentando unir estas dos justificando y uniendo cosas que suceden en la historia con la jugabilidad. Me encanta como intenta justificar todo, evitando así disonancias entre el juego y su historia. También noto las ventajas que tiene una historia simple y bastante fantástica.
 Es cuestión de que lo juegues y lo notes. Es un ejemplo de que no hace falta una historia super compleja ni emotiva en un videojuegos para que funcione y encaje bien con la jugabilidad. (Aún así, no le estoy sacando méritos a las obras que sí se animan a ese tipo de historias) Aunque supongo que lo de la historia va un poco más sobre gustos.

[h1] Conclusión [/h1]

Me parece un juego bastante sobresaliente, y estoy seguro de que no soy al único que le parece así, tan solo es mirar ese 97% de reseñas positivas. Es un metroidvania perfecto para las personas que no conocen el género y les gustaría probar algún juego del estilo, porque como dije, sabe mantener el ritmo increíblemente bien y es difícil sentirse perdido. Algo malo que podría decir del juego, supongo que es su duración, se termina haciendo un poco corto en comparación otros juegos del mismo género, pero para mí no es un problema. De todos modos, una vez terminás la historia principal se desbloquea toda una zona extra, por si te quedaste con ganas de más.

En fin, [b] juego recomendadísimo. [/b] Me gustó tanto que le saqué todos los logros.

85250024.review:
Touhou Luna Nights has all the upsides you'd expect to see in a 'major' Touhou game and much more. The art design and soundtrack are on point to recreate Gensokyo's great fantasy setting. In addition, the gameplay mechanics work very well together. Instead of replacing each other or rendering the previous ones useless, new mechanics allow for new combinations and new strategies.

In my opinion, the difficulty is a bit on the easy side no matter what you do. That's mostly because the Graze mechanic can be easily abused and often ends up rewarding you more than it should. One way or another, it's a great game that fans of the Metroidvania and action platformer genres shouldn't miss.

85244827.review:
I wanted to like this game. I really did. I love Touhou, and I love platformers, and this game's got tons of good reviews, so I thought I'd have a good time but I really didn't.
There are good parts, to be fair. The art is fantastic, and there are tons of nice stylistic choices like how the rain in the first area slows / stops so you can see the individual droplets. Some of the puzzles related to stopping / starting time are really interesting. It controls great for the most part too. The music is okay, but not good enough that I'd listen to it over the original music from EoSD. But that's about all the good I can say about this game.
The issues I have with this game fall into two fairly distinct categories: how it is as a game and how it is as a Touhou work.

[u]How it is as a game[/u]
For starters, this isn't a metroidvania, regardless of what people say. If anything's preventing your progress, you'll find a key or upgrade that lets you continue in that same area. You don't need to backtrack to earlier areas at any time unless you want collectibles (which for the most part don't make a difference but I'll get to that later). That's probably a good thing, because the warp placement makes no sense at all, mostly placed on the edges of areas instead of being centralized for easy access.
Up until the third area, the game's fairly mediocre. You control great, but no enemies pose any challenges, so it's pretty boring. From the third area onward, the game seems to be incentivizing you to skip all the enemies by stopping time and running past them, because you can graze enemies to continually refill your time meter and all you get from killing them is money (which doesn't matter, I never went to the shop) or EXP (which as far as I can tell does nothing). This trend continues through the whole game. As rooms become more cramped and enemies become stronger and bulkier, you learn it's far easier to stop time and ignore everything than it is to bother fighting, which will have a much higher chance of you dying. At that point, all the collectibles and cool spells mean nothing. Why bother getting +10 MP or a shiny new spell if you're never going to use it against an enemy?
On a side note, Snail Time doesn't need MP or time points to activate, which seems odd considering the massive effect it can make on gameplay.
The bosses are even more disappointing, again due to the imbalance of the graze feature. Every boss is depressingly easy, because not only are most of their attacks laughably pathetic (Meiling's "super" attack is literally just one of her regular attacks but with a much longer startup, for crying out loud), but they all have one attack that you can abuse to gain tons of graze outside of stopped time, which basically refills half your health for free easily. They all also only have like three to five attacks at the most (even the final boss!), which combined with an HP pool that could bear to be cut in half and your base attack requiring that you use your MP, which recharges at the speed of a snail, means that 70% of bosses are you just dodging their attacks with ease while you wait for your MP to recharge. Collectibles yet again make no difference because the extra HP will just be full all the time, the extra MP will just reduce how fast it takes for you to drain it to zero, and the special moves all take more MP than they're worth as far as I can tell (though apparently Thousand Knives is overpowered to the point of being super unbalanced, but that just changes boss fights from "boring slog" to "spam without thinking", so that's a totally different problem). The game tries to disincentivise usage of the time stop during boss battles by firing attacks that only move in stopped time, but they don't bother doing it alongside attacks that move normally so the second that you see those attacks you can just stop time, let them fly offscreen, and just continue. The final boss is even more awful, because in addition to everything above, she has two phases and dying on the second phase because you don't know how to deal with the lasers the first time you see them forces you to take two minutes wearing down the first phase again, and aside from the cheap kill when the lasers come out the first time, said final boss is just as pathetic as the other bosses for all the same reasons.
The game's also super short, clocking in about 3 hours (probably more if you go collectible hunting, but why would you when they do almost nothing?) for a first playthrough. I can't really justify paying slightly under $20 for an unfun and boring journey that you can knock out in one night.
Also the game crashed against the final boss when I tried to graze her second phase in stopped time, so that's neat.
In summary, this game incentivizes you to skip all of its levels through timestop and slows to a crawl during bosses with attacks that pose no threat and an awful MP system.

[u]How it is as a Touhou work[/u]
Touhou games are characterized by fun bosses where you have very little room to move and are always engaged with exciting and difficult new attacks. It's a series where you have to die a lot and persevere to eventually grasp the satisfaction of finally defeating the difficult spellcard you've been stuck on for god knows how long. In stark parallel, bosses in Luna Nights are hilariously easy, incredibly lenient, and honestly boring because you're always running out of MP and have to sit around doing nothing, a notion that's alien to any mainline Touhou game. Whereas the levels in Touhou games are challenges that you have to path out that are ultimately just leading up to the fun bosses, the levels of Luna Nights are obnoxiously difficult, orders of magnitude harder than the bosses, if you play them straight, and are total meaningless filler if you skip them with time stop.
So this game completely messes up the design philosophy of the actual Touhou games, but that was probably obvious by how the actual Touhou games are fun and this game isn't.

[u]And now for some Touhou-related nitpicks![/u]
None of these are really anything gameplay-related, but they bother me so I'm putting them here.
I could complain about how all the characters are from EoSD with exceptions that barely matter, but that's just me being irritable with the overrepresentation of one game in Touhou fanworks rather than Luna Nights itself. Even so, it hurts whenever I see another fangame that focuses on the SDM instead of a group that's more developed / could use more development, like the Undergrounders or Eientei or Myouren or literally any non-EoSD game.
Plus the game kinda makes limited use of / misuses the characters it has. Meiling does literally nothing interesting, but she gets a pass because she's the first boss. Marisa at least has Earthlight Ray, Master Spark, and some slave-type spell, but she's missing her trademark star bullets. Patchouli uses all her elements solo instead of ever combining them. [spoiler]Nitori[/spoiler] uses a weird mech instead of her neato backpack. [spoiler]Flandre[/spoiler] uses massive crystal wings instead of leaning into her huge retinue of interesting spellcards, with the only one making an appearance predictably being Laevateinn. Finally, [spoiler]Reimu[/spoiler] uses the paper end of her weapon instead of the kicks and whacks that she's more known for.

This is a really good-looking game. I wish it was a good-playing one too.

85220510.review:
So I have just about 0 exposure to Touhou outside of music covers on YouTube and random snippets of fan art, but the reviews here were pretty glowing and I love Metroidvanias so I decided to give it a go anyway...

and BOY am I glad I did! I'm happy to report that no knowledge of Touhou is required to fully enjoy the game.  Quite frankly, I feel like this game has gotten less attention than it deserves probably due to the Touhou branding putting off people unfamiliar with the franchise. Rock solid Metroidvania designed around the fascinating mechanic of being able to slow or outright stop time at will. With great music (It is Touhou lol), beautiful pixel art, super tight controls and fantastic boss battles this is an easy recommendation to anyone who likes the genre. People who've played Rabi-Ribi in particular will feel right at home with the bullet-hell inspired bosses.

Game is on the short side, and honestly easier than I'd have liked (turns out being able to stop time is pretty good) but the price is right for the length and quality. The praise is 100% warranted, Touhou fan or no.

85159220.review:
A metroidvania set in the Touhou universe (which I know almost nothing about) & defines itself w/ several unique gameplay elements & gimmicks. 

You play as Sakuya, a knife throwing maid. You primary attack is, obviously, throwing a flurry of knives, but these knives use mp to throw. You also have a pocket watch that freezes time, allowing you to que up attacks, run across water, dodge attacks, etc. This pocket watch burns its own 'time gauge' instead of mp.
Now if you just narrowly avoid enemy's hit-boxes & attacks you get a 'graze' (an element linking it to its parent series of shoot-em-ups). Grazes restores a small amount of hp & during a time freeze it restores mp instead.
So much of the gameplay has you seamlessly shifting time while managing your time gauge, dodging attacks & throwing out clouds of knives.

You'll journey through the world of Touhou, confronting many of the popular characters on a journey to prove yourself to your vampire employer, Remilia.

Team Ladybug did a good job. High quality pixel art & animation, unique mechanics & an absolutely bangin' soundtrack.
